<div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The American Astronomical Society (AAS), established in 1899 and based in Washington, DC, is the major organization of professional astronomers in North America. Its membership of about 7,000 individuals also includes physicists, mathematicians, geologists, engineers, and others whose research and educational interests lie within the broad spectrum of subjects comprising contemporary astronomy. The mission of the AAS is to enhance and share humanity's scientific understanding of the universe.</p> <p><a href=\"https://aas.org/\">https://aas.org/</a></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n</a>\n<span class=\"overlay-set\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel\">\n        <a title=\"Close\"  class=\"close-icon close-overlay\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\" aria-describedby=\"close-icon-description\"><span class=\"icon-close\"></span></a>\n        <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.</p>\n        <div class=\"overlay-img\">\n            <a href=\"\">\n                <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The Institute of Physics (IOP) is a leading scientific society promoting physics and bringing physicists together for the benefit of all. It has a worldwide membership of around 50 000 comprising physicists from all sectors, as well as those with an interest in physics. It works to advance physics research, application and education; and engages with policy makers and the public to develop awareness and understanding of physics. Its publishing company, IOP Publishing, is a world leader in professional scientific communications.</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.iop.org\">https://www.iop.org</a></p></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<p></p>\n                </div>\n        </div>\n    </div>\n<!-- Branded journal header ends -->\n</div> <!-- end secondary-header -->\n<!-- Secondary header ends --><div class=\"da1-da2\" itemscope=\"\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/ScholarlyArticle\" id=\"page-content\">\n            <div class=\"da1 ta1 article-head\">\n                <!-- Start Eyebrow block, containing Surtitle and Labels -->\n<div class=\"eyebrow\">\n\t<!-- Start Collection Labels -->\n    <!-- End Collection Labels --> </div>\n<!-- End Eyebrow block -->\n\n<h1 itemprop=\"headline\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-title\">THE CFHTLS\u2013STRONG LENSING LEGACY SURVEY (SL2S): INVESTIGATING THE GROUP-SCALE LENSES WITH THE SARCS SAMPLE<SUP>*</SUP>       </h1>\n\n<p class=\"mb-0\">\n\t<span data-authors=\"\">\n\t\t<span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">A. data-toolbar-container=\"table\"></div>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<div class=\"nav-item wd-in-pg-toolbar-ref\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href=\"\" class=\"nav-top-link-drop-down article-toolbar-dropdown\" data-toolbar-action=\"references\" data-nav-trigger=\"references\">References<span class=\"icon-arrow-down\"></span></a>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<div class=\"nav-drop-down\" data-nav-item=\"references\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<div class=\"overflow-y\" data-toolbar-container=\"references\"></div>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<div class=\"nav-item wd-in-pg-toolbar-artdata\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href=\"\" class=\"nav-top-link-drop-down article-toolbar-dropdown\" data-toolbar-action=\"artdata\" data-nav-trigger=\"artdata\">Article data<span class=\"icon-arrow-down\"></span></a>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<div class=\"nav-drop-down\" data-nav-item=\"artdata\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<div class=\"overflow-x mb-05\" data-toolbar-container=\"artdata\"></div>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<p class=\"small\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"/journal/0004-637X/page/article-data\">What is article data?</a></p>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t</nav>\n\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"nav-in-page-active-grid-2 d-n\">\n\t\t\t\t\t<aside>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<div class=\"pdf-button-2nd\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t\t\t</aside>\n\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t</div>\n\t</div>\n</div>\n<!-- End toolbar --></div>\n            <div class=\"da2 ta2\">\n                <div class=\"print-hide content-tools\">\n\t\t\t<div>\n\t<p>\n\t\t<span id=\"total-downloads\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-total-dwnlds\"><b>2505</b> Total downloads</span>\n\t\t\t<br />\n\t\t</p>\n\t</div>\n\t\n<div class=\"dimensions-altmetric-li\">\n\n        <!-- Start Dimensions display -->\n        <!-- Start Dimensions display -->\n    <span <span class=\"icon-newtab\">\n            </a></p>\n        </div>\n\n    <!-- End Email Alert -->\n<!-- End Email Alert --><!-- Start Citation Alert Link -->\n                        <p>\n<div class=\"jnl-notifications-wrapper\">\n    <a class=\"wd-jnl-email-alert\" href=\"https://myiopscience.iop.org/signin?origin=a0&return=https%3A%2F%2Fiopscience.iop.org%2Fmyiopscience%2Falerts%2Fsubscribe%3FarticleID%3D0004-637X%2F749%2F1%2F38\"><span\n            class=\"icon-alarm icon-alarm--jhp\"></span>Create citation alert</a>\n</div><!-- End Citation Alert Link -->\n                    </div>\n\t\t</div>\n    </div>\n    <!-- Article information ends -->\n<!-- Start Info top-->\n    <!-- end Info top --><div class=\"article-content\">\n\t<span id=\"articleId\" class=\"hide\">0004-637X/749/1/38</span>\n<!-- Start Abstract -->\n    <h2 id=\"artAbst\" class=\"collapse-blocked\">Abstract</h2>\n        <!-- Start article video abstract -->\n\t<!-- End article video abstract -->\n\t<div class=\"article-text wd-jnl-art-abstract cf\" itemprop=\"description\">\n                      <P>We present the Strong Lensing Legacy Survey-ARCS (SARCS) sample compiled from the final T0006 data release of the Canada-France-Hawaii Telescope Legacy Survey (CFHTLS) covering a total non-overlapping area of 159\u00a0deg<SUP>2</SUP>. We adopt a semi-automatic method to find gravitational arcs in the survey that makes use of an arc-finding algorithm. The candidate list is pruned by visual inspection and ranking to form the final <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample. This list also includes some serendipitously discovered lens candidates which the automated algorithm did not detect. The <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample consists of 127 lens candidates which span arc radii ~2''-18'' within the unmasked area of ~150\u00a0deg<SUP>2</SUP>. Within the sample, 54 systems are promising lenses among which, we find 12 giant arcs (length-to-width ratio &#x2265;8). We also find two radial arc candidates in SL2SJ141447+544704. From our sample, we detect a systematic alignment of the giant arcs with the major axis of the baryonic component of the putative lens in concordance with previous studies. This alignment is also observed for all arcs in the sample and does not vary significantly with increasing arc radius. The mean values of the photometric redshift distributions of lenses corresponding to the giant arcs and all arcs sample are at <I>z</I> ~ 0.6. Owing to the large area and depth of the CFHTLS, we find the largest sample of lenses probing mass scales that are intermediate to cluster and galaxy lenses for the first time. We compare the observed image separation distribution (ISD) of our arcs with theoretical models. A two-component density profile for the lenses which accounts for both the central galaxy and the dark matter component is required by the data to explain the observed ISD. Unfortunately, current levels of uncertainties and\u00a0degeneracies accommodate models both with and without adiabatic contraction. We also show the effects of changing parameters of the model that predict the ISD and that a larger lens sample might constrain relations such as the concentration-mass relation, mass-luminosity relation, and the faint-end slope of the luminosity function.</P>       </div>\n    <!-- End abstract -->\n<!-- Start Export citation and abstract tools -->\n\t<p>\n\t\t<small>Export citation and abstract</small>\n\t\t<span class=\"btn-multi-block\">\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/export?articleId=0004-637X/749/1/38&doi=10.1088/0004-637X/749/1/38&exportFormat=iopexport_bib&exportType=abs&navsubmit=Export+abstract\" class=\"btn btn-primary wd-btn-cit-abs-bib\" title=\"Export BibTex\">BibTeX</a>\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/export?articleId=0004-637X/749/1/38&doi=10.1088/0004-637X/749/1/38&exportFormat=iopexport_ris&exportType=abs&navsubmit=Export+abstract\" class=\"btn btn-primary wd-btn-cit-abs-ris\" title=\"Export RIS\">RIS</a>\n\t\t</span>\n\t</p>\n<!-- End Export citation and abstract tools -->\n<!-- Start AAS Related Links -->\n<div class=\"reveal-container reveal-closed reveal-plus-icon bdt-1 mt-2 mb-2 wd-jnl-art-article-aas-related-links\">\n  <div class=\"replica-h3 mt-0\">\n    <a href=\"#\" class=\"reveal-trigger\" data-reveal-label-alt=\"Hide related links\">Related links</a>\n  </div>\n  <div class=\"reveal-content\">\n    <div class=\"article-meta\"> \n      <ul>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2012ApJ...749...38M\" target=\"_blank\">NASA ADS Record <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://nedwww.ipac.caltech.edu/cgi-bin/nph-objsearch?refcode=2012ApJ...749...38M&search_type=Search \" target=\"_blank\">NED Objects <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-ref?querymethod=bib&simbo=on&bibcode=2012ApJ...749...38M\" target=\"_blank\">Simbad Objects <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"/journal/0004-637X/page/About%20Related%20Links\" target=\"_blank\">About Related Links</a></li>\n      \t</ul>\n    </div>\n  </div>\n</div>\n<!-- Start info bottom -->\n    <!-- End info bottom -->\n<!-- Start article full text -->\n\t<div xmlns:book=\"http://api.iop.org/Book/1.0/\" itemprop=\"articleBody\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-full-text article-text\">\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj421966s1\" name=\"apj421966s1\">1.\u00a0INTRODUCTION</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>Gravitational lensing is the deflection of light coming from distant sources in the universe, due to the gravitational potential of intervening structures (see reviews, e.g., Blandford &amp; Narayan <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r10\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r10\">1986</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r11\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r11\">1992</a>; Kochanek <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r47\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r47\">2006</a>). The last decade has seen the rise of a wide variety of applications of strong lensing such as the study of distant lensed galaxies with unprecedented magnification (e.g., Impellizzeri et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r39\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r39\">2008</a>; Swinbank et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r96\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r96\">2009</a>; Zitrin &amp; Broadhurst <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r112\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r112\">2009</a>; Richard et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r85\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r85\">2011</a>), the constraints on substructure within lensing halos (e.g., More et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r70\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r70\">2009a</a>; Suyu &amp; Halkola <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r94\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r94\">2010</a>; Vegetti et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r104\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r104\">2010a</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r105\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r105\">2010b</a>), accurate measurements of the Hubble constant (e.g., Coles <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r17\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r17\">2008</a>; Suyu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r95\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r95\">2010</a>), constraints on the stellar initial mass function (e.g., Treu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r99\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r99\">2010</a>; Ferreras et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r28\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r28\">2010</a>; Sonnenfeld et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r93\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r93\">2011</a>), constraints on the slope of the inner density profile of the lensing halos (e.g., Treu &amp; Koopmans <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r100\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r100\">2002a</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r101\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r101\">2002b</a>; Koopmans &amp; Treu <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r51\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r51\">2003</a>; Koopmans et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r52\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r52\">2006</a>; More et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r71\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r71\">2008</a>; Barnab\u00e8 et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r6\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r6\">2009</a>; Koopmans et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r50\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r50\">2009</a>), and estimation of the fraction of dark matter in galaxy-scale halos (e.g., Gavazzi et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r29\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r29\">2007</a>; Jiang &amp; Kochanek <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r41\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r41\">2007</a>; Grillo et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r33\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r33\">2010</a>; Faure et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r25\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r25\">2011</a>; More et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r69\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r69\">2011a</a>; Ruff et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r87\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r87\">2011</a>).</p><p>Although strong lensing is a rare event, several surveys covering a wide sky area and deep enough imaging across different wavelengths have resulted in the discovery of over 200 strong lens systems at galaxy scales from surveys such as, the Great Observatories Origins Deep Survey (Fassnacht et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r24\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r24\">2004</a>), Cosmic Evolution Survey (COSMOS; Faure et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r26\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r26\">2008</a>; Jackson <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r40\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r40\">2008</a>), Mediu Deep Survey (Ratnatunga et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r84\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r84\">1999</a>), the Cosmic Lens All Sky Survey (CLASS; Myers et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r75\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r75\">2003</a>), and the Sloan Lens ACS Survey (SLACS; Bolton et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r13\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r13\">2006</a>) and about a few dozen lens systems at cluster scales such as, the Extended Medium Sensitivity Survey (EMSS; Luppino et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r60\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r60\">1999</a>), the MAssive Cluster Survey (MACS; Ebeling et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r22\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r22\">2001</a>), the Las Campanas Distant Cluster Survey (LCDCS; Zaritsky &amp; Gonzalez <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r111\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r111\">2003</a>), and the Red sequence Cluster Survey (RCS; Gladders et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r30\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r30\">2003</a>, henceforth G03). Large imaging and spectroscopic surveys enable us to probe statistical properties of both dark matter and baryonic matter or constrain cosmological parameters with high accuracy. For instance, on galaxy scales, the SLACS sample has been used to study the average density profiles of lens galaxies up to redshift of ~0.3 (e.g., Koopmans et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r52\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r52\">2006</a>; Gavazzi et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r29\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r29\">2007</a>; Koopmans et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r50\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r50\">2009</a>; Auger et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r3\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r3\">2010</a>), Falco et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r23\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r23\">1999</a>) used the CfA-Arizona Space Telescope LEns Survey (CASTLES; Mu\u00f1oz et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r74\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r74\">1998</a>) sample to measure the mean extinction due to the interstellar medium of the lens galaxies, Mediavilla et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r64\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r64\">2009</a>) estimated the fraction of mass in compact objects within lens galaxies from the CASTLES, and Wyithe (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r109\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r109\">2004</a>) constrained the bright end of the quasar luminosity function from the absence of lensed quasars at high redshift in the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS). On cluster scales, G03 found that the observed abundance of giant arcs from the RCS is too high to be consistent with the predictions from the current standard cosmological model (see also Bartelmann et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r7\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r7\">1998</a>; Li et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r55\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r55\">2005</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r56\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r56\">2006</a>) and Zitrin et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r113\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r113\">2011</a>) found some discrepancy between the predictions from the standard model and the observed distribution of Einstein radii from the MACS sample. However, the magnitude of these differences has been mitigated with subsequent studies (e.g., Horesh et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r37\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r37\">2005</a>; Meneghetti et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r67\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r67\">2011</a>).</p><p>As discussed above, the majority of the surveys in the past have primarily focused on studying galaxy-scale or cluster-scale structures. As a result, matter distribution in galaxies and galaxy clusters is relatively well studied via both strong and weak lensing. A further improvement in our understanding has come from the use of complementary methods to lensing such as stellar kinematics, satellite kinematics, and X-ray scaling relations. In contrast, little is known about galaxy groups which are intermediate to galaxies and galaxy clusters, typically corresponding to masses of 10<sup>12</sup>\u201310<sup>14</sup>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub>. Relatively fewer investigations have been carried out with galaxy groups, e.g., study of the intra-group medium with a very low redshift X-ray sample (Helsdon &amp; Ponman <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r35\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r35\">2000</a>), study of mass-to-light ratios with the Canadian Network for Observational Cosmology 2 sample (Parker et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r82\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r82\">2005</a>), study of the faint end of the luminosity function of nearby compact groups (Krusch et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r53\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r53\">2006</a>), study of the concentration\u2013mass (<em>c</em>\u2013<em>M</em>) relation from SDSS (Mandelbaum et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r62\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r62\">2008</a>) via weak lensing, study of colors and star formation (e.g., Balogh et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r4\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r4\">2009</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r5\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r5\">2011</a>), study of the scaling relations of X-ray selected groups (Rines &amp; Diaferio <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r86\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r86\">2010</a>), and study of baryon fractions from the Two Micron All Sky Survey (Dai et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r20\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r20\">2010</a>). Since studies of groups are limited, we still do not have a detailed understanding of matter distribution, formation, and evolution of galaxy groups. Being one of the important components in the hierarchical assembly of structures in the universe, galaxy groups are much more massive than galaxy-scale halos and are concentrated enough to act as lenses. Furthermore, since galaxy groups are quite abundant compared to massive structures like galaxy clusters, the probability of finding group-scale lenses is also large. Hence, lensing can be successfully used to study group-scale halos.</p><p>The Strong Lensing Legacy Survey (SL2S; Cabanac et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r16\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r16\">2007</a>) is a survey from the Canada\u2013France\u2013Hawaii Telescope Legacy Survey (CFHTLS). The design of CFHTLS allows us to find large sample of group-scale lenses, which can be studied in detail upto high redshifts, for the first time. The SL2S is as a precursor to wide-field imaging surveys such as the Dark Energy Survey, Large Synoptic Survey Telescope, and Euclid. A combined study of SL2S galaxy-scale lenses with the SLACS sample have been used to show mild evolution of the slope of the average density profile of galaxies (Ruff et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r87\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r87\">2011</a>) which is constrained by the strong lensing and stellar dynamics techniques. Disk galaxies are also a relatively less studied population especially at high redshifts. An automated search for edge-on disk lenses from the SL2S resulted in 18\u00a0candidates, out of which three to five are expected to be real lenses (Sygnet et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r97\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r97\">2010</a>). A subset of the SL2S groups have been studied in detail using a combination of techniques such as strong lensing, group dynamics, weak lensing to probe the density profiles of the lensing groups (e.g., Limousin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r57\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r57\">2009</a>; Thanjavur et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r98\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r98\">2010</a>; Verdugo et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r106\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r106\">2011</a>).</p><p>In this paper, we present the SL2S-ARCS (SARCS) sample from the final T0006 release of the CFHTLS. In Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj421966s2\">2</a>, we give an overview of the survey and procedure of sample selection, describe details of the algorithm, <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> (Alard <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r1\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r1\">2006</a>), and present the final sample. In Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj421966s3\">3</a>, we discuss some statistical results using the final sample. In Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj421966s4\">4</a>, we summarize the survey and our main findings.</p></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj421966s2\" name=\"apj421966s2\">2.\u00a0THE CFHTLS\u2013SL2S-ARCS SAMPLE</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>In this section, we give a brief overview of the survey from which we derive the lens sample. This is followed by a description of the semi-automatic process of selecting the candidates in the final sample. We also discuss how the algorithm, <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> works and the modifications implemented in the new <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span>. Last, we present the final sample and report duplicate detections of some candidates from other surveys.</p><h3 id=\"apj421966s2-1\" name=\"apj421966s2-1\">2.1.\u00a0Survey Overview</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>CFHTLS is a photometric survey made with the Canada\u2013France\u2013Hawaii Telescope (CFHT) in five optical bands (<em>u</em>*<em>g</em>'<em>r</em>'<em>i</em>'<em>z</em>') using the wide-field imager MegaPrime with a field of view of 1\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> on the sky and a pixel size of 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />186. The <span class=\"small-caps\">WIDE</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">DEEP</span> components of the CFHTLS are designed to carry out extragalactic research. These components are ideal for searching strong lens systems. The SL2S sample is compiled from the <span class=\"small-caps\">CFHTLS-WIDE</span> encompassing a combined area of 171\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> and <span class=\"small-caps\">CFHTLS-DEEP</span> encompassing a combined area of 4\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup>. However, taking into account the masked and overlapping areas, the effective area of the survey is 150.4\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> (146.9\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> for <span class=\"small-caps\">WIDE</span> and 3.5\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> for DEEP). The <span class=\"small-caps\">WIDE</span> consists of four fields, W1, W2, W3, and W4. Field W1 has the largest sky coverage of 63.65\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup>. Fields W2 and W4 have similar sky coverages of 20.32\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> and 20.02\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup>, respectively.<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apj421966fn2\">8</a></sup> Field W3 has a sky coverage of 42.87\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> and is more than twice as large as W2 and W4. <span class=\"small-caps\">DEEP</span> also consists of four fields, D1 (located within the W1 field), D2, D3, and D4. Each of the deep fields covers an area of 1\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup>. The DEEP images are produced in two image stacks D-25 and D-85. The former consists of 25% of the best seeing images and the latter consists of 85% of the best seeing images. We use the D-25 images for searching lens candidates. Among the <span class=\"small-caps\">WIDE</span> fields, <em>g</em>-band imaging is the deepest of all bands with a limiting magnitude of 25.47 and a mean seeing of 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />78 whereas the <em>g</em>-band imaging of <span class=\"small-caps\">DEEP</span> fields has nearly 10 times deeper exposures than the <span class=\"small-caps\">WIDE</span> fields and the median seeing is ~0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />7. The zero point to convert flux to AB magnitude for all bands is 30. Further details of the T0006 release, which is the first complete release of the <span class=\"small-caps\">WIDE</span> and DEEP, can be found on Terapix Web site.<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apj421966fn3\">9</a></sup></p></div><h3 id=\"apj421966s2-2\" name=\"apj421966s2-2\">2.2.\u00a0Sample Selection</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The SL2S lens sample is compiled using two algorithms: <span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span>. The former aims at detecting galaxy-scale lenses by using color information. The SL2S RINGS sample will be presented and discussed in a separate paper (R. Gavazzi et al., in preparation). Here, we focus on the SARCS sample created with the help of <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span>, followed by visual inspection and screening of the candidates.</p><p>We define the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample such that lens systems with arc radius (<em>R</em><sub>A</sub>) <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/gsim.gif\" alt=\"gsim\" align=\"baseline\" /> 2'' belong to the sample. The radius of the arc is defined as the distance of the lensed image from the putative lens galaxy which is roughly the Einstein radius. Typically, lensing halos with Einstein radius larger than 2'' are very massive lenses with significant contribution from the environment of the primary lensing galaxy. Thus, the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample predominantly consists of group to cluster-scale lenses. Lens systems with <em>R</em><sub>A</sub> &lt; 2'', typically, form part of the <span class=\"small-caps\">R</span>INGS sample. We note that a few lens systems are common to both SL2S samples since the cut on <em>R</em><sub>A</sub> is not a sharp limit imposed by the algorithms.</p><p>The <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample from CFHTLS is compiled in a three-step process. The first step is to run the arc-detection algorithm called <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span>. We choose to run the <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> on the <em>g</em>-band image since most of the lensed images correspond to galaxies with high star formation that have little emission at redder wavelengths. Also, focusing on the <em>g</em> band prevents us from detecting high-redshift <em>g</em>-dropouts. However, we plan to search for <em>g</em>-dropout arcs which are brighter in the <em>i</em> band. These results will be presented in a separate paper.</p><p>At the end of the first step, we produce a list of arc candidates with various parameters. The next step is applying a cutoff on arc properties such as the area, the peak flux count, and the radius of curvature, and rejecting candidates within masked area. These cuts allow a significant reduction in false detections at the cost of losing some real arc candidates. In the third step, visual inspection and classification are carried out to grade the quality of the candidates. Note that the final <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample consists of candidates that are detected by the <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> and/or by visual inspection.</p></div><h3 id=\"apj421966s2-3\" name=\"apj421966s2-3\">2.3.\u00a0Automatic Detection of Arcs: <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span></h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>With the advent of several large imaging surveys, searching for lens systems visually is a subjective and time-expensive exercise which may not be easily repeatable. Hence, several algorithms have been devised in the last few years to automate the process of lens detection as much as possible. The algorithms, usually, focus on a specific target population, for example, algorithms to detect the lensed sources such as quasars via the quasar time variability (Kochanek et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r48\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r48\">2006</a>) based on the difference imaging technique of Alard &amp; Lupton (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r2\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r2\">1998</a>), spectrum-based algorithms such as the one used by Bolton et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r14\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r14\">2004</a>) to form the SLACS sample following the technique of Warren et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r108\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r108\">1996</a>) or lens-modeling robots that assesses the probability of a bright red galaxy being a lens (Marshall et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r63\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r63\">2009</a>). Since groups to cluster-scale lenses form arc-like lensed images, there are a few arc-finders in the literature (e.g., Lenzen et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r54\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r54\">2004</a>; Horesh et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r37\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r37\">2005</a>; Seidel &amp; Bartelmann <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r91\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r91\">2007</a>) that aim at detecting elongated arc-like images.</p><p>The <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> (Alard <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r1\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r1\">2006</a>) is a generic algorithm that can be used to detect elongated and curved features in an image. The algorithm uses pixel intensities from a standard FITS image to trace the structure of a feature. Multiple thresholds are applied to the structural properties of the feature to select an arc candidate. The reader is referred to Alard (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r1\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r1\">2006</a>) for the details of the algorithm. Below, we describe the algorithm along with some modifications implemented in the newer version (V2.0), which is used to compile the SARCS sample.</p><p>We show a flowchart to illustrate the various steps involved in the algorithm (see Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj421966f1\">1</a>) and step through an example of a mock arc image (see Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj421966f2\">2</a>).\n</p><ul class=\"clear-list wd-inline-list\"><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">1.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">We run the <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> on images of 19354<b>&#x00d7;</b>19354\u00a0pixels, which corresponds to a single MEGACAM pointing. For such large images, the assumption of Gaussian distribution for the noise holds well. Assuming a Gaussian distribution for the noise in the input image (panel 1 of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj421966f2\">2</a>), the noise \u03c3 is calculated in the first step. Most of the arcs are unresolved with the ground-based telescopes like CFHT and are limited by the size of the point-spread function (PSF).</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">2.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">Convolving the image with a smoothing kernel, with a size of the order of the PSF, can help damp the noise and enhance the detection of arcs. Hence, the input image is smoothed with a Mexican-hat filter in the next step (panel 2 of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj421966f2\">2</a>).The Mexican-hat bandpass filter with scale <em>b</em> is given by\n<div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj421966fd1\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966fd1.gif\" alt=\"Equation (1)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{equation} M(x,y)=e^{-\\bar{r}^2}-0.5e^{-\\frac{\\bar{r}^2}{2}} \\,, \\end{equation}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t1\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div>where <em>b</em><sup>2</sup> = 3\u00a0pixels and\n<div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj421966fd2\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966fd2.gif\" alt=\"Equation (2)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{equation} \\bar{r}=\\frac{\\sqrt{x^2+y^2}}{b} \\,. \\end{equation}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t2\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div></div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">3.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">Now, we define a local estimator of elongation for every pixel in the smoothed image. This is calculated by using the flux from all pixels within a window centered on every pixel. The size of the window is chosen to be a few times the PSF size. We consider a square window of side <em>W</em> centered on the pixel at (<em>x</em>, <em>y</em>). Using the second-order moments of brightness distribution within the window, the local direction of the elongation of the feature is calculated. This direction is then used to align the feature along the <em>x</em>-axis to determine the local axis ratio, similar to a length-to-width ratio, within the window. The elongation estimator is defined as follows:\n<div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj421966fd3\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966fd3.gif\" alt=\"Equation (3)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{equation} Q(x,y)= \\frac{1}{W} \\frac{F_{\\rm X}}{F_{\\rm Y_{\\rm max}}} \\,, \\end{equation}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t3\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div>where <em>F</em><sub>X</sub> is the integrated flux of the single central row of pixels and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966ieqn1.gif\" alt=\"$F_{\\rm Y_{\\rm max}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">F_{\\rm Y_{\\rm max}}</script></span></span> is the maximum of the integrated flux values calculated from single columns of pixels within the window. If <em>F</em><sub>X</sub> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966ieqn2.gif\" alt=\"$F_{\\rm Y_{\\rm max}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">F_{\\rm Y_{\\rm max}}</script></span></span> are above (<em>W</em> + 1)0.75\u03c3 (threshold 1 in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj421966f1\">1</a> and Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj421966t1\">1</a>), then the estimator <em>Q</em>(<em>x</em>,\u00a0<em>y</em>) is assigned to the pixel (<em>x</em>, <em>y</em>) at the center of the window or else the pixel is assigned a value of 0. Likewise, the estimator is calculated for every pixel in the image (see panel 3 of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj421966f2\">2</a>).</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">4.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">In the following step, we attempt to connect the pixels that possibly belong to the candidate arc. A pixel is accepted if the estimator value from the image in panel 3 is &gt;1.25 (threshold 2 in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj421966f1\">1</a> and Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj421966t1\">1</a>). The estimator is set to 0 as soon as a pixel is connected in the prior step to avoid repetitive checking of connected pixels. Iterating the above steps over the image allows tracing of the primary shape of the arc. If the number of connected pixels is more than 10 (threshold 3) then the properties of arcs such as the length, peak flux, and surface brightness are calculated. Panel 4 shows the image with connected pixels, which, for the case at hand, consists of one candidate only. The estimator is particularly suited for recovering pixels along the length of the arc. In order to connect the pixels along the width of the arc, we use the input and smoothed images (panels 1 and 2, respectively). Using arcs with length &gt;7 pixels, we apply surface brightness thresholds on pixel values from images in panels 1 and 2 in order to accept pixels belonging to the arc (threshold 4; see Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj421966f1\">1</a> and Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj421966t1\">1</a>) and construct the arc fully.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">5.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">In the last step, if the candidate arc satisfies thresholds on the arc properties such as the width (&#x2265;1.5 and &#x2264;8\u00a0pixels), area (&gt;25\u00a0pixels), surface brightness (&gt;2\u03c3), and peak flux (&lt;500 ADU\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pixel<sup>\u22121</sup>) which correspond to threshold 5 in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj421966f1\">1</a>, then the arc is accepted (see panel 5 in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj421966f2\">2</a>).</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">6.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">In the following, we describe how the arc properties are measured. The area of the arc is the total number of pixels belonging to the final arc. The length of the arc is calculated by assuming that the candidate arc is similar to an arc of a circle. We first find the extreme ends of the arc, connect them with a chord labeled AB in panel 6 of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj421966f2\">2</a>. From the midpoint E of chord AB, we draw a line perpendicular to the chord and find its intersection D with the arc. The lengths ED and AB uniquely identify the circle to which the arc belongs and as well as the length of the arc. The width of the arc is defined as the ratio of the area to the length of the arc. The radius of the circle going through the arc is used as a proxy for the curvature of the arc.</div></li></ul><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj421966f1\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj421966f1\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966f1_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 1.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 1.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966f1_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 1.</strong>\u00a0Flowchart showing the <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> algorithm.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj421966f1\" href=\"/0004-637X/749/1/38/downloadFigure/figure/apj421966f1\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj421966f1\" href=\"/0004-637X/749/1/38/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj421966f1\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj421966f2\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj421966f2\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966f2_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 2.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 2.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966f2_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 2.</strong>\u00a0Outputs of <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> at various stages of the execution (panels 1\u20135) using a mock arc image. Panel 1: original image with the mock arc; panel 2: smoothed image; panel 3: (disconnected) pixels with elongation estimator values higher than a threshold; panel 4: connected pixels above thresholds that belong to the arc; and panel 5: the reconstructed shape of the final arc. The image is 11<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />3 on a side. Schematic diagram for measuring length of an arc (panel 6).</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj421966f2\" href=\"/0004-637X/749/1/38/downloadFigure/figure/apj421966f2\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj421966f2\" href=\"/0004-637X/749/1/38/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj421966f2\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apj421966t1\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 1.</b>\u00a0Thresholds used in the Final Selection of the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> Candidates</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj421966t1\" data-toolbar-img=\"/0004-637X/749/1/38/suppdata/apj421966t1_lr.gif\" data-toolbar-type=\"table\" data-toolbar-title=\"Table 1\"><colgroup><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col></colgroup><thead>\n<tr valign=\"top\"><th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Step</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Parameters and Thresholds</th></tr>\n</thead><tbody><tr valign=\"top\"><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">Smooth</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"><em>W</em> = 9, <em>b</em><sup>2</sup> = 3.0</td></tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\"><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">Detect</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"><em>W</em> = 11, Th1 = 11*0.75\u03c3</td></tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\"><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">Connect</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"><em>W</em> = 9, Th2 = 1.25</td></tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\"><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">\u00a0</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"><em>W</em> = 9, Th4 = 0.5S1,0.3S2</td></tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\"><td class=\"rowsep\" colspan=\"2\" rowspan=\"1\"></td></tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">Properties</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">Final Thresholds</td></tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\"><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">Area</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">55 &lt; <em>A</em> &lt; 500 (pixel)</td></tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\"><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">Peak counts</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">&lt;50 (ADU s<sup>\u22121</sup>)</td></tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\"><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">Mean counts</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">2\u03c3 &lt; SB &lt; 50 (ADU s<sup>\u22121</sup> pixel<sup>\u22121</sup>)</td></tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\"><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">Length</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">&gt;7 (pixel)</td></tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\"><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">Width</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">1.5 &#x2264; <em>w</em> &#x2264; 8 (pixel)</td></tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\"><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">Curvature</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"><em>r<sub>c</sub></em> &lt; 100 and <em>r<sub>c</sub></em> &gt; 1000 (pixel)</td></tr></tbody></table><p><small>\n<strong>Notes.</strong> <em>W</em> is the window size in pixels. Th1, Th2, and Th4 imply thresholds 1, 2, and 4, respectively. S1 and S2 imply intermediate mean counts of candidates in the input and smoothed images, respectively.</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n            Download table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/749/1/38/suppdata/apj421966t1_ascii.txt?doi=10.1088/0004-637X/749/1/38\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/749/1/38/suppdata/apj421966t1_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>In the algorithm, the use of a second image at another wavelength and a mask file are optional. The algorithm, in its current version, merely prints the values of the pixels belonging to the candidate arc from the image 2 and/or the mask file, if provided. This allows us to optionally screen the candidate arcs based on their color and/or masking information. For the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample, we made use of the mask option only and further restricted the parameter space of the output list of arcs by introducing more strict cuts on some of the arc properties. Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj421966t1\">1</a> lists the final set of thresholds which are satisfied by the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> candidates detected by <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span>.</p><p>The components enclosed by the dashed line in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj421966f1\">1</a> are the sections of the algorithm that have been improved. This includes the way in which the pixels belonging to the arc are connected and the way the properties of the arcs are measured. In the earlier version of the algorithm, a candidate arc is accepted at the final stage only if it satisfies a certain threshold on the curvature of the arc. This feature has been removed and the option of using mask information is introduced in the V2.0. The values for all the different thresholds are tuned from an initial sample of <span class=\"small-caps\">CFHTLS</span> arcs, found visually or from the previous version of <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span>, based on an early release of the data. Furthermore, all the thresholds can now be set during the execution of the algorithm.</p><p>The <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> V2.0 finds ~1.5 times more detections, most of which arise due to spikes and halos near stars. However, the use of masks removes these false detections, thereby making the number of detections comparable to or less than the output of the earlier version. The modified <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> is over three times faster than the earlier version. We have also recently parallelized the algorithm, which enables us to achieve even faster computation on shared memory platforms. The <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> V2.0 is available upon request to the author.</p><p>Finally, we note that the existing algorithms are far from perfect and almost always require manual intervention. Attempts to increase the completeness of the sample almost always leads to a corresponding increase in the rate of false positives. In light of these issues, citizen science projects such as the Galaxy Zoo (Lintott et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r59\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r59\">2008</a>) might be a better tool, for the time being, in identifying lens systems not detected by the algorithms. These projects, in turn, could be used to calibrate and improve existing algorithms. We are currently pursuing the feasibility of such a project.</p></div><h3 id=\"apj421966s2-4\" name=\"apj421966s2-4\">2.4.\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> Sample</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>After the automatic detection and screening, about 1000\u00a0candidates\u00a0deg<sup>\u22122</sup> are visually inspected. This is reduced to a total sample of 413 candidates, which is further considered for ranking by three people. The individually assigned ranks are from 1 to 4 with 1 being the least likely to 4 being the almost certain lens system. We present the 127 lens candidates which are ranked 2 or higher (average of the ranks by three people) and which have <em>R</em><sub>A</sub> <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/gsim.gif\" alt=\"gsim\" align=\"baseline\" /> 2''. All of the 127 candidates<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apj421966fn4\">10</a></sup> are listed in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj421966t2\">2</a>, which gives the ID, lens position, lens magnitudes in AB, lens redshifts with 1\u03c3 uncertainties, arc radii, ranks, the type indicating whether the candidates are primarily detected via the <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> and the field name in which the candidate is located. For the calculation of arc radii in physical units, we use flat cosmology with following parameters (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966ieqn3.gif\" alt=\"$\\Omega _m,\\Omega _\\Lambda ,H_0$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\Omega _m,\\Omega _\\Lambda ,H_0</script></span></span>)=(0.3,0.7,100\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup>). The symbol A stands for detection by <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> and V implies that a candidate is found serendipitously. A total of 54 candidates are good-to-best systems (that is, a rank of 3 and above) and are shown in Figures <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj421966f3\">3</a> and\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj421966f4\">4</a>. Out of the total sample, 27 systems have been or are being followed up for further analyses (see Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj421966t3\">3</a>) and most of them are confirmed lens systems, 5 systems are very likely lenses and rest of the 96 are possible lenses. Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj421966t3\">3</a> does not report information about any archival data on any of the lens candidates.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj421966f3\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj421966f3\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966f3_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 3.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 3.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966f3_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 3.</strong>\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample showing the 54 promising lens systems with a rank of 3 and above. All color cutouts are made from CFHT imaging in <em>g</em>, <em>r</em>, and <em>i</em> bands. The cutouts are ~30'' on a side. region as per the catalog from which the magnitudes and the redshift are extracted. <strong><em>z</em>:</strong> the magnitudes and/or redshift are not from the Coupon et al. catalog instead are measured by the author using sextractor and/or <span class=\"small-caps\">zebra</span> (Feldmann et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r27\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r27\">2006</a>), respectively. <strong><em>C</em>:</strong> this lens is identified in both D2 and COSMOS fields. Note that other lenses within D2 have not been reported in the COSMOS lens sample (Faure et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r26\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r26\">2008</a>). <strong><em>R</em>:</strong> this lens is also found in RCS (see G03). <strong><em>G</em>:</strong> this lens is also a part of the SL2S-RINGS colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.334, \u00a0\u22c5\u22c5\u22c5</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">S, H</td></tr></tbody></table><p><small>\n<strong>Notes.</strong> Col 3: L09-Limousin et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r57\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r57\">2009</a>), L10\u2014Limousin et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r58\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r58\">2010</a>), T10\u2014Thanjavur et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r98\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r98\">2010</a>), R11\u2014Ruff et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r87\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r87\">2011</a>), V11\u2014Verdugo et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r106\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r106\">2011</a>) and M11\u2014Mu\u00f1oz et al. (2012, in prep, PI\u2014V. Motta, ESO-080.A-0610). VM is assigned to those systems which are being followed up for spectroscopy with the VLT by V. Motta (PI, ESO-086.A-0412). Col 4: Spectroscopic redshifts for the lens galaxy and lensed source from the follow-up observations along with their error bars, if available. Col 5: V\u2014VLT, K\u2014Keck, and G\u2014Gemini indicate telescopes used for follow-up spectroscopy and S-SDSS spectroscopy. H corresponds to <em>HST</em> imaging followed up by J-P. Kneib (PI, C15 and C16) and/or R. Gavazzi (PI, C17).</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n            Download table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/749/1/38/suppdata/apj421966t3_ascii.txt?doi=10.1088/0004-637X/749/1/38\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/749/1/38/suppdata/apj421966t3_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>One of the deep fields, D2, has an overlap with the COSMOS (Scoville et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r90\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r90\">2007</a>), a photometric survey of 1.8\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> in the <em>I</em> band (limiting magnitude of 26.5) with the Advanced Camera Survey (ACS) on board the <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>). We find two of the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> candidates common to the lens sample of COSMOS (Faure et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r26\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r26\">2008</a>). The <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> candidates with IDs SA78 and SA83 are known COSMOS candidates and the rest of the six candidates within the COSMOS field are new (see Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj421966t2\">2</a> with field labeled as D2). For comparison, we also show the ACS images of the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> candidates in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj421966f5\">5</a> from the COSMOS archive. The W3 field overlaps with one of the 22 individual fields of the RCS survey which covers a combined area of ~90\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup>. The overlapping RCS field has a lensing cluster, RCS 1419.2+5326 at <em>z</em> = 0.64. This cluster is also detected in the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample identified by SA102 (see Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj421966t2\">2</a>).</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj421966f5\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj421966f5\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966f5_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 5.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 5.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966f5_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 5.</strong>\u00a0<em>HST</em> <em>I</em>-band (F814W) imaging of the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> lens candidates within the D2 field extracted from the COSMOS archive. The IDs and coordinates are labeled for each system. The arrows point toward the putative lensed arcs. The arc in SA79 is too faint to be visible in the <em>I</em>-band <em>HST</em> image shown here. All candidates are new detections except SA78 (COSMOS ID: 5939+3044) and SA83 (COSMOS ID: 0211+1139). The images are 6'' on a side. North is up and east is left.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj421966f5\" href=\"/0004-637X/749/1/38/downloadFigure/figure/apj421966f5\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj421966f5\" href=\"/0004-637X/749/1/38/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj421966f5\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj421966s3\" name=\"apj421966s3\">3.\u00a0RESULTS AND DISCUSSION</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>In the following subsections, we describe the main findings from the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample and constraints on average properties of the lens population using statistical properties of the arcs. Note that many of the lens candidates are not confirmed lenses yet and hence the results should be taken as indicative. First, based on the photometric redshifts of the lenses, we study the lens redshift distribution. Subsequently, we discuss about the abundance of giant arcs and presence of radial arcs in the sample. Finally, we measure the azimuthal distribution and image separation distribution (ISD) of the arcs and argue their importance as diagnostics for understanding the matter distribution of the lenses, statistically.</p><h3 id=\"apj421966s3-1\" name=\"apj421966s3-1\">3.1.\u00a0Lens Redshift Distribution</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The lenses producing giant arcs (e.g., length-to-width ratio &#x2265;10) consist of clusters which lie at the high end of the halo mass function. The redshift distribution and abundance of such massive clusters depend on the parameters of a cosmological model. Bartelmann et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r7\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r7\">1998</a>) estimated that most of the lensing clusters giving rise to giant arcs should peak at around <em>z</em> ~ 0.3\u20130.4 for the currently accepted standard cosmological model.</p><p>We use the <span class=\"small-caps\">CFHTLS</span> photometric redshift catalogs (Coupon et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r19\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r19\">2009</a>), which are generated from the code <span class=\"small-caps\">le phare</span> (Ilbert et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r38\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r38\">2006</a>) to calculate the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> lens redshift distribution. The accuracy on the redshifts of galaxies in the <span class=\"small-caps\">WIDE</span> with magnitudes <em>i</em>\u2009 &lt; \u200921.5 is \u03c3<sub>\u0394<em>z</em>/(1 + <em>z</em>)</sub>\u2009 ~ \u20090.037 and with magnitudes 22.5\u2009 &lt; \u2009<em>i</em>\u2009 &lt; \u200923.5 is \u03c3<sub>\u0394<em>z</em>/(1 + <em>z</em>)</sub>\u2009 ~ \u20090.08. In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj421966f6\">6</a>, we show the redshift distribution for all the lenses in the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample (solid histogram) and for lenses consisting of giant arcs only (dashed histogram). In Appendix\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj421966app2\">B</a>, we describe how we estimated the mean and 1\u03c3 uncertainty given the redshift measurement errors (see Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj421966t2\">2</a>). We find that the mean of the lens redshift distribution for the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample is <em>z</em>\u2009 = \u20090.58 \u00b1 0.22 and that for the sample of giant arcs is <em>z</em>\u2009 = \u20090.64 \u00b1 0.19. We note that the mean of the giant arcs sample is at a higher redshift compared to the peak expected from Bartelmann et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r7\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r7\">1998</a>) but certainly consistent within 2\u03c3 confidence interval. For comparison, the RCS sample G03 finds that most of the lenses with giant arcs have redshifts upward of ~0.6.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj421966f6\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj421966f6\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966f6_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 6.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 6.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966f6_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 6.</strong>\u00a0Redshift distributions of the lens galaxies from the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample. The solid histogram corresponds to lenses from the whole sample whereas the dashed histogram corresponds to lenses with giant arcs only. The respective means of their redshift distributions are <em>z</em> = 0.58 \u00b1 0.22 and <em>z</em> = 0.64 \u00b1 0.19 where the uncertainties indicate a 68% confidence level.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj421966f6\" href=\"/0004-637X/749/1/38/downloadFigure/figure/apj421966f6\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj421966f6\" href=\"/0004-637X/749/1/38/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj421966f6\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>We make a qualitative comparison of the redshift distributions of the lens populations from other surveys in the literature (not shown in the figure). However, we note that these surveys have significantly different selection functions and hence quantitative conclusions should not be drawn. The distribution of lens sample from CASTLES<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apj421966fn5\">11</a></sup> peaks between 0.3 and 0.4, which is lower than the mean redshift of the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample. CASTLES has a large enough sample of lenses but is not homogeneously selected. Nevertheless, the peaks are consistent within 2\u03c3 (assuming an error of 0.05) in spite of the differences in the sample selection. The COSMOS lens sample (Faure et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r26\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r26\">2008</a>), on the other hand, is fairly homogeneous but the sample size of confirmed lenses is relatively small. COSMOS has a bimodal lens redshift distribution with a minimum at ~0.5\u20130.6. This is in stark contrast with the redshift distribution of <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> (see Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj421966f6\">6</a>).</p></div><h3 id=\"apj421966s3-2\" name=\"apj421966s3-2\">3.2.\u00a0Giant and Radial Arcs</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Here, we report detections of giant and radial arcs from our sample. The arcs, both radial and tangential, produced in massive clusters are conventionally referred to as giant arcs, if their length-to-width (<em>l</em>/<em>w</em>) ratio is larger than about 8 or 10. For a (non-singular) circularly symmetric projected density profile, the inverse magnification matrix of a lensed image has two eigenvectors, one in the radial and the other in the tangential direction. If the radial eigenvalue becomes 0, then the arcs are magnified and stretched radially with respect to the center of the lens and are called radial arcs. If the tangential eigenvalue becomes 0, then the arcs are magnified and stretched tangentially and are called tangential arcs.</p><h4 id=\"apj421966s3-2-1\" name=\"apj421966s3-2-1\">3.2.1.\u00a0Giant Arcs</h4><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The statistics of giant arcs allows the detection of clusters at the massive end of halo mass function that are rare. The statistics of such rare massive structures is sensitive to the cosmological model of the universe. Hence, several attempts have been made to predict the giant arcs statistics (e.g., Bartelmann et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r7\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r7\">1998</a>; Wambsganss et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r107\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r107\">2004</a>; Dalal et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r21\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r21\">2004</a>, henceforth, D04) that suggested a large discrepancy compared to the observed abundance of arcs from a well-defined cluster population (e.g., Luppino et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r60\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r60\">1999</a>; Gonzalez et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r32\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r32\">2001</a>; Gladders et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r30\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r30\">2003</a>; Li et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r55\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r55\">2005</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r56\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r56\">2006</a>). However, the discrepancy has been substantially diminished due to more realistic assumptions such as using a realistic source redshift distribution and improved predictions which consider the contribution of central galaxy or substructure within the halos (e.g., Meneghetti et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r66\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r66\">2000</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r65\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r65\">2003</a>; Horesh et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r37\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r37\">2005</a>).</p><p>We present the abundance of giant arcs in our sample, which could be tested with predictions from realistic simulations by taking into account the observational limitations. Within a total unmasked area of ~150\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup>, eight of the arcs have <em>l</em>/<em>w</em> of ~10 or above. Additionally, four more arcs have <em>l</em>/<em>w</em>\u2009 ~ \u20098, which are included in the sample of giant arcs because these appear to be broken either due to noise or due to a satellite galaxy. Since one of the giant arcs is from DEEP, we use the rest of the 11 giant arcs from the <span class=\"small-caps\">WIDE</span> data for comparison with RCS. We use the primary sample of RCS, which has a roughly similar depth compared to <span class=\"small-caps\">WIDE</span> data. The primary RCS lens sample has six arcs with <em>l</em>/<em>w</em> &#x2265; 8 found within a total area of 90\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> G03. Therefore, the RCS sample has 0.07 \u00b1 0.03 arcs\u00a0deg<sup>\u22122</sup> which is consistent with the 0.07 \u00b1 0.02 arcs\u00a0deg<sup>\u22122</sup> from the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample.</p></div><h4 id=\"apj421966s3-2-2\" name=\"apj421966s3-2-2\">3.2.2.\u00a0Radial Arcs</h4><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The radial arcs are formed when the source falls on the radial caustic (see Appendix <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj421966app1\">A</a>). The size of the radial caustic and hence, the cross section to form radial arcs depends on the slope of inner regions of the density profile of the lens (e.g., Hattori et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r34\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r34\">1999</a>). The statistics of radial arcs can thus be used to constrain the slope of the central density profiles of clusters and thereby allow a better understanding of the nature of dark matter (Molikawa &amp; Hattori <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r68\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r68\">2001</a>).
