This cluster is also detected in the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample identified by SA102 (see Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj421966t2\">2</a>).</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj421966f5\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj421966f5\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966f5_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 5.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 5.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966f5_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 5.</strong>\u00a0<em>HST</em> <em>I</em>-band (F814W) imaging of the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> lens candidates within the D2 field extracted from the COSMOS archive. The IDs and coordinates are labeled for each system. The arrows point toward the putative lensed arcs. The arc in SA79 is too faint to be visible in the <em>I</em>-band <em>HST</em> image shown here. All candidates are new detections except SA78 (COSMOS ID: 5939+3044) and SA83 (COSMOS ID: 0211+1139). The images are 6'' on a side. North is up and east is left.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj421966f5\" href=\"/0004-637X/749/1/38/downloadFigure/figure/apj421966f5\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj421966f5\" href=\"/0004-637X/749/1/38/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj421966f5\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj421966s3\" name=\"apj421966s3\">3.\u00a0RESULTS AND DISCUSSION</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>In the following subsections, we describe the main findings from the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample and constraints on average properties of the lens population using statistical properties of the arcs. Note that many of the lens candidates are not confirmed lenses yet and hence the results should be taken as indicative. First, based on the photometric redshifts of the lenses, we study the lens redshift distribution. Subsequently, we discuss about the abundance of giant arcs and presence of radial arcs in the sample. Finally, we measure the azimuthal distribution and image separation distribution (ISD) of the arcs and argue their importance as diagnostics for understanding the matter distribution of the lenses, statistically.</p><h3 id=\"apj421966s3-1\" name=\"apj421966s3-1\">3.1.\u00a0Lens Redshift Distribution</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The lenses producing giant arcs (e.g., length-to-width ratio &#x2265;10) consist of clusters which lie at the high end of the halo mass function. The redshift distribution and abundance of such massive clusters depend on the parameters of a cosmological model. Bartelmann et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r7\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r7\">1998</a>) estimated that most of the lensing clusters giving rise to giant arcs should peak at around <em>z</em> ~ 0.3\u20130.4 for the currently accepted standard cosmological model.</p><p>We use the <span class=\"small-caps\">CFHTLS</span> photometric redshift catalogs (Coupon et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r19\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r19\">2009</a>), which are generated from the code <span class=\"small-caps\">le phare</span> (Ilbert et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r38\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r38\">2006</a>) to calculate the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> lens redshift distribution. The accuracy on the redshifts of galaxies in the <span class=\"small-caps\">WIDE</span> with magnitudes <em>i</em>\u2009 &lt; \u200921.5 is \u03c3<sub>\u0394<em>z</em>/(1 + <em>z</em>)</sub>\u2009 ~ \u20090.037 and with magnitudes 22.5\u2009 &lt; \u2009<em>i</em>\u2009 &lt; \u200923.5 is \u03c3<sub>\u0394<em>z</em>/(1 + <em>z</em>)</sub>\u2009 ~ \u20090.08. In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj421966f6\">6</a>, we show the redshift distribution for all the lenses in the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample (solid histogram) and for lenses consisting of giant arcs only (dashed histogram). In Appendix\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj421966app2\">B</a>, we describe how we estimated the mean and 1\u03c3 uncertainty given the redshift measurement errors (see Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj421966t2\">2</a>). We find that the mean of the lens redshift distribution for the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample is <em>z</em>\u2009 = \u20090.58 \u00b1 0.22 and that for the sample of giant arcs is <em>z</em>\u2009 = \u20090.64 \u00b1 0.19. We note that the mean of the giant arcs sample is at a higher redshift compared to the peak expected from Bartelmann et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r7\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r7\">1998</a>) but certainly consistent within 2\u03c3 confidence interval. For comparison, the RCS sample G03 finds that most of the lenses with giant arcs have redshifts upward of ~0.6.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj421966f6\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj421966f6\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966f6_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 6.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 6.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966f6_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 6.</strong>\u00a0Redshift distributions of the lens galaxies from the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample. The solid histogram corresponds to lenses from the whole sample whereas the dashed histogram corresponds to lenses with giant arcs only. The respective means of their redshift distributions are <em>z</em> = 0.58 \u00b1 0.22 and <em>z</em> = 0.64 \u00b1 0.19 where the uncertainties indicate a 68% confidence level.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj421966f6\" href=\"/0004-637X/749/1/38/downloadFigure/figure/apj421966f6\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj421966f6\" href=\"/0004-637X/749/1/38/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj421966f6\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>We make a qualitative comparison of the redshift distributions of the lens populations from other surveys in the literature (not shown in the figure). However, we note that these surveys have significantly different selection functions and hence quantitative conclusions should not be drawn. The distribution of lens sample from CASTLES<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apj421966fn5\">11</a></sup> peaks between 0.3 and 0.4, which is lower than the mean redshift of the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample. CASTLES has a large enough sample of lenses but is not homogeneously selected. Nevertheless, the peaks are consistent within 2\u03c3 (assuming an error of 0.05) in spite of the differences in the sample selection. The COSMOS lens sample (Faure et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r26\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r26\">2008</a>), on the other hand, is fairly homogeneous but the sample size of confirmed lenses is relatively small. COSMOS has a bimodal lens redshift distribution with a minimum at ~0.5\u20130.6. This is in stark contrast with the redshift distribution of <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> (see Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj421966f6\">6</a>).</p></div><h3 id=\"apj421966s3-2\" name=\"apj421966s3-2\">3.2.\u00a0Giant and Radial Arcs</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Here, we report detections of giant and radial arcs from our sample. The arcs, both radial and tangential, produced in massive clusters are conventionally referred to as giant arcs, if their length-to-width (<em>l</em>/<em>w</em>) ratio is larger than about 8 or 10. For a (non-singular) circularly symmetric projected density profile, the inverse magnification matrix of a lensed image has two eigenvectors, one in the radial and the other in the tangential direction. If the radial eigenvalue becomes 0, then the arcs are magnified and stretched radially with respect to the center of the lens and are called radial arcs. If the tangential eigenvalue becomes 0, then the arcs are magnified and stretched tangentially and are called tangential arcs.</p><h4 id=\"apj421966s3-2-1\" name=\"apj421966s3-2-1\">3.2.1.\u00a0Giant Arcs</h4><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The statistics of giant arcs allows the detection of clusters at the massive end of halo mass function that are rare. The statistics of such rare massive structures is sensitive to the cosmological model of the universe. Hence, several attempts have been made to predict the giant arcs statistics (e.g., Bartelmann et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r7\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r7\">1998</a>; Wambsganss et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r107\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r107\">2004</a>; Dalal et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r21\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r21\">2004</a>, henceforth, D04) that suggested a large discrepancy compared to the observed abundance of arcs from a well-defined cluster population (e.g., Luppino et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r60\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r60\">1999</a>; Gonzalez et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r32\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r32\">2001</a>; Gladders et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r30\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r30\">2003</a>; Li et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r55\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r55\">2005</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r56\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r56\">2006</a>). However, the discrepancy has been substantially diminished due to more realistic assumptions such as using a realistic source redshift distribution and improved predictions which consider the contribution of central galaxy or substructure within the halos (e.g., Meneghetti et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r66\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r66\">2000</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r65\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r65\">2003</a>; Horesh et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r37\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r37\">2005</a>).</p><p>We present the abundance of giant arcs in our sample, which could be tested with predictions from realistic simulations by taking into account the observational limitations. Within a total unmasked area of ~150\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup>, eight of the arcs have <em>l</em>/<em>w</em> of ~10 or above. Additionally, four more arcs have <em>l</em>/<em>w</em>\u2009 ~ \u20098, which are included in the sample of giant arcs because these appear to be broken either due to noise or due to a satellite galaxy. Since one of the giant arcs is from DEEP, we use the rest of the 11 giant arcs from the <span class=\"small-caps\">WIDE</span> data for comparison with RCS. We use the primary sample of RCS, which has a roughly similar depth compared to <span class=\"small-caps\">WIDE</span> data. The primary RCS lens sample has six arcs with <em>l</em>/<em>w</em> &#x2265; 8 found within a total area of 90\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> G03. Therefore, the RCS sample has 0.07 \u00b1 0.03 arcs\u00a0deg<sup>\u22122</sup> which is consistent with the 0.07 \u00b1 0.02 arcs\u00a0deg<sup>\u22122</sup> from the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample.</p></div><h4 id=\"apj421966s3-2-2\" name=\"apj421966s3-2-2\">3.2.2.\u00a0Radial Arcs</h4><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The radial arcs are formed when the source falls on the radial caustic (see Appendix <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj421966app1\">A</a>). The size of the radial caustic and hence, the cross section to form radial arcs depends on the slope of inner regions of the density profile of the lens (e.g., Hattori et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r34\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r34\">1999</a>). The statistics of radial arcs can thus be used to constrain the slope of the central density profiles of clusters and thereby allow a better understanding of the nature of dark matter (Molikawa &amp; Hattori <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r68\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r68\">2001</a>). More thorough investigations have been carried out to test the effects of realistic assumptions of properties such as lens ellipticity, source size, and ellipticity on the statistics of radial and tangential arcs (e.g., Keeton <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r43\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r43\">2001</a>; Oguri <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r79\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r79\">2002</a>). Sand et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r89\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r89\">2005</a>) used archival <em>HST</em> (WFPC2) data on various lensing cluster samples to do a systematic study of the number ratio of radial-to-tangential arc statistics. They accounted for the effects due to the central galaxy in the expected number ratio and placed loose constraints on the slope of the average inner density profile of the dark matter. They underlined the need of larger observational data sets to further explore effects of substructure, mass of the central galaxy, and homogeneity of the sample.</p><p>We report detections of radial arc candidates in the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample during the visual inspection. We found one candidate which appears like a radial arc in the system SL2SJ141447+544704 (SA100 in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj421966t2\">2</a>). This lens system also has a giant tangential arc (T1) with the same color as the radial arc (R1; see the left panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj421966f7\">7</a>). The subsequent <em>HST</em> observation in the F606W band shows another radial arc candidate (R2; see the right panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj421966f7\">7</a>). The nature of the radial arc candidates needs to be verified with spectroscopy and mass modeling since these could be blue edge-on disk galaxies. Radial arcs are usually faint and are overshadowed by the bright central galaxies near which they are formed. Nevertheless, we argue that a follow-up imaging of the promising <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> candidates at high resolution will help in creating a homogeneous sample of radial and tangential arcs which could provide crucial insights in understanding the density distributions in the inner regions of the lens systems.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj421966f7\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj421966f7\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966f7_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 7.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 7.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966f7_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 7.</strong>\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">CFHTLS</span> <em>gri</em> image of SL2SJ141447+544704 (SA100) on the left and <em>HST</em> F606W (<em>V</em> band) image on the right. The high resolution of <em>HST</em> suggests two radial arc candidates labeled as R1 and R2 whereas the tangential arc labeled as T1 is a confirmed lensed arc. The <span class=\"small-caps\">CFHTLS</span> image is 74<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />4 on a side and the <em>HST</em> image is ~28<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />3 on a side.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj421966f7\" href=\"/0004-637X/749/1/38/downloadFigure/figure/apj421966f7\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj421966f7\" href=\"/0004-637X/749/1/38/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj421966f7\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure></div></div><h3 id=\"apj421966s3-3\" name=\"apj421966s3-3\">3.3.\u00a0Galaxy-arcs Orientation</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>In this section, we quantify the angular distribution of arcs with respect to the major axis of the ellipticity of the lensing halo. D04 suggested that triaxial dark matter halos, when acting as lenses, usually form lip caustics (e.g., Hattori et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r34\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r34\">1999</a>) and the formation of giant arcs tends to be at the ends of the lip caustics. Using numerical simulations, they showed that the giant arcs are oriented very close to the major axis of the dark matter halo. If a central galaxy is further added to the halo, it then appeared to isotropize the angular distribution of arcs to a small extent. In order to compare these predictions to the observations, D04 measured the angular distribution of giant arcs from the EMSS cluster sample under the assumption that the ellipticity of the lensing galaxy is a good representation of the ellipticity of the underlying DM halo. They found that most of the giant arcs had an orientation of &lt;45\u00a0deg, consistent with their predictions.</p><p>We use the same definition as that used in D04 for the orientation of the arcs, that is, the angle between the major axis of the lens galaxy and the line connecting the center of the lens galaxy to the midpoint of the arc. The measurement of orientation of real arcs tends to be somewhat subjective since there exists an ambiguity in defining the extent of the arc, which is required to find the midpoint of the arc. The midpoint of the arc and its orientation from the major axis of the lens is calculated manually. When there is a single dominant lensing galaxy we measure the position angle (P.A.) of the major axis of the lens galaxy with S<span class=\"small-caps\">extractor</span> (Bertin &amp; Arnouts <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r9\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r9\">1996</a>); otherwise we adopt the following strategy. If there are two or three (nearly collinear) lens galaxies with similar colors and brightness, then the P.A. of the ellipticity is assumed to be along the line joining the lens galaxies. If a circle going through the arc encloses multiple lens galaxies with comparable brightness but no obvious elongation, then such a system is rejected. If one of the lens galaxies is predominantly brighter than the companion galaxies, then the ellipticity of the dominant galaxy is assumed to reflect the overall ellipticity of the gravitational potential and hence, of the caustics.</p><p>After applying the above selection cuts, we are left with 36 all-arc candidates and 11 giant arcs with an average ranking &gt;2.5. The angular distribution of the giant arcs from the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample is shown in the left panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj421966f8\">8</a>. We compare the observed distribution to the expected distributions from D04 which correspond to two cases: (1) for dark-matter-only lensing halo (solid curve) and (2) a dark matter halo to which a galaxy of 3 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>12</sup>\u2009<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub> is added (dashed curve). The distribution of giant arcs from our sample appears to follow the expected trend although it is not possible to distinguish between the two cases. We also show the distribution of orientation of all-arc candidates (see the left panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj421966f8\">8</a>) which seems to follow the expected anisotropy. This extends the result obtained by D04 to group-scale lens systems. Furthermore, we split the all-arcs sample into small <em>R</em><sub>A</sub> (&lt;5'') and large <em>R</em><sub>A</sub> (&gt;\u2009 = \u20095'') samples to see the dependence of the angular distribution on the Einstein radius (or the arc radius). The choice of cut at 5'' is arbitrary. The baryonic matter tends to make the matter distribution in halos more spherical at the center. Therefore, the angular distribution of arcs for the sample with smaller <em>R</em><sub>A</sub> is expected to be more isotropic compared to the sample with large <em>R</em><sub>A</sub>. However, we do not find any clear differences in the angular distribution of small and large <em>R</em><sub>A</sub> for the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample within the uncertainties (see the right panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj421966f8\">8</a>). We note that these measurements may have some systematic errors due to the orientation dependence of the selection function. Ambiguities also exist in the definition of the orientation in few cases, especially when multiple candidate lens galaxies are involved. In addition, the current analysis consists of lens candidates as opposed to confirmed lens systems. Therefore, our conclusions should be treated more of a qualitative nature.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj421966f8\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj421966f8\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966f8_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 8.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 8.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966f8_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 8.</strong>\u00a0Angular distribution of arcs with respect to the lens galaxy. The data points in both the panels are from the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample. In the right panel, the \"all arcs\" sample is divided into small and large <em>R</em><sub>A</sub>. The expected curves for dark matter (DM) only (solid) and DM + 3 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>12</sup>\u2009<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub> (dashed) are taken from D04, which are calculated from the cluster sample of the GIF simulation (Kauffmann et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r42\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r42\">1999</a>).</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj421966f8\" href=\"/0004-637X/749/1/38/downloadFigure/figure/apj421966f8\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj421966f8\" href=\"/0004-637X/749/1/38/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj421966f8\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure></div><h3 id=\"apj421966s3-4\" name=\"apj421966s3-4\">3.4.\u00a0Image Separation Distribution</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The ISD is sensitive to the halo mass, the abundance of the lens population, the mass distribution in the lens, and the source redshift. Therefore, the ISD measured from galaxy to cluster scales contains information about the cosmological parameters and various scaling relations between galaxy properties and halo mass. Hitherto, the ISD has been measured either at small image separations (\u03b8) primarily, with lens samples such as CASTLES (e.g., Keeton et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r44\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r44\">2000</a>; Khare <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r46\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r46\">2001</a>) and CLASS (e.g., Kochanek &amp; White <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r49\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r49\">2001</a>; Oguri <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r80\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r80\">2006</a>) or at large \u03b8 with cluster-scale lenses, for example, the MACS sample (Zitrin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r113\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r113\">2011</a>). With the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample, we can probe the intermediate-mass regime corresponding to group-scale lenses. The <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample is selected based on the presence of elongated arc-like features and is not directly biased toward selecting a specific lens population. The ISD measured from the lens samples is referred to as the observed ISD and the ISD calculated from various models is referred to as the expected/predicted ISD throughout this paper.</p><h4 id=\"apj421966s3-4-1\" name=\"apj421966s3-4-1\">3.4.1.\u00a0Model for the Expected Distribution</h4><div class=\"article-text\"><p>In the past, the expected ISD was computed with models consisting of either galaxy-dominated (e.g., Turner et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r102\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r102\">1984</a>) or dark-matter-dominated lensing halos (e.g., Narayan &amp; White <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r77\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r77\">1988</a>). However, since the density profile of dark matter is known to be affected due to the presence of baryons at the center, the need for a more complex model to explain the observed ISD was pointed out by Keeton et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r45\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r45\">1998</a>) and demonstrated by subsequent studies (e.g., Porciani &amp; Madau <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r83\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r83\">2000</a>; Kochanek &amp; White <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r49\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r49\">2001</a>; Oguri <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r80\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r80\">2006</a>, henceforth O06). We follow the framework developed in O06 and Oguri et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r81\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r81\">2002</a>) to calculate the expected ISD in order to compare it with the observed ISD from the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample. We also adopt the cosmology used in O06 which constitutes of the following cosmological parameters: \u03a9<sub><em>m</em></sub> = 0.3, \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub> = 0.7, and \u03c3<sub>8</sub> = 0.9. We describe in detail how each of the model parameters are calculated before proceeding to the comparison of various models.</p><p>The probability for a source at redshift, <em>z<sub>s</sub></em>, to get lensed with image separation greater than \u03b8 is given by\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj421966fd4\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966fd4.gif\" alt=\"Equation (4)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray} P (>\\theta ;z_s) &=& \\int _0^{z_s} dz_l \\frac{d\\chi }{dz_l} \\int _{0}^{\\infty } dM \\, n(M,z_l) \\nonumber \\\\ &&\\times \\sigma _{{\\rm lens}}\\, \\Theta (M-\\tilde{M}) \\,, \\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t4\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where \u03c7 is the comoving distance, <em>z<sub>l</sub></em> is the redshift of the lens, <em>M</em> corresponds to the halo mass, <em>n</em>(<em>M</em>, <em>z<sub>l</sub></em>) is the halo mass function, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966ieqn4.gif\" alt=\"$\\tilde{M}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\tilde{M}</script></span></span> is the minimum halo mass that causes an image separation equal to \u03b8, and \u0398 is the Heaviside step function. The biased lensing cross section, \u03c3<sub>lens</sub> is measured in comoving units and is given by\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj421966fd5\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966fd5.gif\" alt=\"Equation (5)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{equation} \\sigma _{\\rm lens}= \\pi y_r^2 \\xi _0^2 B(z_s) \\,, \\end{equation}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t5\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where <em>y<sub>r</sub></em>\u03be<sub>0</sub> corresponds to the radius of the outermost caustic in the lens plane<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apj421966fn6\">12</a></sup> and it depends on the matter density distribution around the lens. The quantity <em>B</em>(<em>z<sub>s</sub></em>) denotes the magnification bias which causes sources, fainter than the limiting magnitude of the survey, to be detected in the sample. It is the ratio of the number of sources that can be potentially lensed into an image with luminosity <em>L</em> to the number of sources that have an intrinsic luminosity <em>L</em>. In general, the magnification bias depends upon the luminosity of the source and under the assumption of spherical symmetry, it is given by\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj421966fd6\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966fd6.gif\" alt=\"Equation (6)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray} &&B(z_s,L)=\\frac{1}{\\pi y_r^2 \\, \\Phi (z_s,L) \\, dL} \\int _0^{y_r} dy \\, 2 \\pi y \\, \\Phi \\Big (z_s,\\frac{L}{\\mu (y)}\\Big) \\frac{dL}{\\mu (y)} \\,, \\nonumber \\\\ \\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t6\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where \u03a6(<em>z<sub>s</sub></em>, <em>L</em>) is the true source luminosity function and \u03bc(<em>y</em>) is the lensing magnification at an angular position <em>y</em> inside the caustic. Under the assumption of a power-law luminosity function which does not evolve with redshift, the luminosity dependence of the magnification bias drops out.</p><p>Differentiating both sides of Equation (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apj421966fd4\">4</a>), we obtain the differential probability\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj421966fd7\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966fd7.gif\" alt=\"Equation (7)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray} \\bigg |\\frac{ dP}{ d\\theta }\\bigg | &=& \\int _0^{z_s} dz_l \\frac{{\\rm d}\\chi }{dz_l} \\int _{0}^{\\infty } \\frac{dM}{d\\theta } \\, n(M,z_l) \\, \\sigma _{{\\rm lens}} \\, \\delta [M-\\tilde{M}(\\theta)] \\nonumber \\\\ &=& \\int _0^{z_s} dz_l \\, \\frac{{\\rm d}\\chi }{dz_l}\\, n(\\tilde{M}[\\theta ],z_l) \\, \\sigma _{{\\rm lens}} \\frac{d\\tilde{M}}{d\\theta } \\,, \\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t7\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>which can be directly related to the ISD of the observed lens sample.</p><p>In O06, the above equation is used to predict the ISD resulting from different components in a given halo. To use the above equation, we have to specify the distribution of mass inside a halo and the halo mass function. The former allows us to calculate <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966ieqn5.gif\" alt=\"$\\tilde{M}(\\theta)$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\tilde{M}(\\theta)</script></span></span> and the biased cross section for lensing. For the latter, O06 assumed the state-of-the-art calibration of the mass function given by Sheth &amp; Tormen (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r92\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r92\">1999</a>). For the mass distribution inside a halo, O06 considered the following different components.\n</p><ul class=\"clear-list wd-inline-list\"><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">1.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">At the center of the dark matter halo, the matter density is dominated by the central galaxy and the total matter distribution is very close to that of a singular isothermal sphere (SIS). This distribution is given in terms of the one-dimensional velocity dispersion (\u03c3<sub>vel</sub>) such that \u03c1(<em>r</em>)\u221d\u03c3<sup>2</sup><sub>vel</sub>/<em>r</em><sup>2</sup>. Following Section 2.3.1 of Oguri et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r81\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r81\">2002</a>), we calculate the size of the radial caustic (<em>y<sub>r</sub></em>\u03be<sub>0</sub>) in comoving coordinates, the total magnification of the lensed images, and the relation between the velocity dispersion and the image separation for the SIS mass distribution. To relate the mass of the halo to the velocity dispersion of the central galaxy, O06 used galaxy scaling relations. They adopted the halo-mass\u2013luminosity relation from Vale &amp; Ostriker (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r103\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r103\">2004</a>) using the abundance matching technique and the Faber\u2013Jackson relation obtained by Bernardi et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r8\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r8\">2003</a>) using SDSS galaxies to relate the luminosity to the velocity dispersion of the galaxy. Following Cooray &amp; Milosavljevi\u0107 (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r18\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r18\">2005</a>), they also included a lognormal scatter in the halo-mass\u2013luminosity relation with a scatter of 0.25 dex (see also More et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r72\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r72\">2009b</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r73\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r73\">2011b</a>).</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">2.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">On large scales, the distribution of dark matter follows the Navarro\u2013Frenk\u2013White (NFW; Navarro et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r78\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r78\">1997</a>) profile given by\n<div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj421966fd8\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966fd8.gif\" alt=\"Equation (8)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{equation} \\rho (r) = \\frac{\\rho _s}{(r/r_s)(1+r/r_s)^2} \\, , \\end{equation}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t8\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div>where the scale radius <em>r<sub>s</sub></em> = <em>R</em><sub>vir</sub>/<em>c</em>; the concentration parameter <em>c</em> is related to the mass <em>M</em> with a considerable scatter. O06 used the mean relation between concentration and mass of Bullock et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r15\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r15\">2001</a>), given by\n<div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj421966fd9\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966fd9.gif\" alt=\"Equation (9)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray} &&\\bar{c}= \\frac{10}{1+z} \\left(\\frac{M}{M_{*}}\\right)^{-0.13} \\,. \\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t9\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div>The distribution of concentrations at fixed halo mass is assumed to be lognormal with a scatter of 0.3 dex. For the NFW case, we calculate the caustic size, the magnification, and the relation between halo mass and the image separation numerically. We defer the details of our procedure to calculate these quantities to Appendix\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj421966app1\">A.</a></div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">3.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">In addition to the above two simple profiles, O06 also considered a combined total profile which included the central galaxy, the dark matter halo, and the effect of adiabatic contraction (AC) of dark matter in response to the baryonic component of the galaxy at the center. In this case, O06 assumed the central galaxy to have a Hernquist profile (Hernquist <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r36\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r36\">1990</a>), given by\n<div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj421966fd10\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966fd10.gif\" alt=\"Equation (10)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray} &&\\rho (r) = \\frac{M_b}{2\\pi }\\frac{1}{(r/r_b)(r_b+r)^3} \\, , \\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t10\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div>where <em>M<sub>b</sub></em> is the stellar mass of the galaxy and <em>r<sub>b</sub></em> is a core radius. The stellar mass <em>M<sub>b</sub></em> was obtained using the halo-mass\u2013luminosity relation found by Vale &amp; Ostriker (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r103\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r103\">2004</a>) and adopting a constant mass-to-light ratio of 3.0<em>h</em><sub>70</sub>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub>/<em>L</em><sub>\u2609</sub>. The scaling relations of Bernardi et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r8\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r8\">2003</a>) can be used to obtain the effective radius <em>R</em><sub>0</sub> as a function of the luminosity of the galaxy, which is related to the core radius of the Hernquist profile such that <em>r<sub>b</sub></em> = 0.551<em>R</em><sub>0</sub>. The AC is carried out using the analytical formalism presented by Gnedin et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r31\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r31\">2004</a>). Having specified the total dark matter distribution, the caustic size, the magnification, and the relation between halo mass and the image separation need to be calculated numerically. We describe the procedure we use in Appendix\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj421966app1\">A.</a></div></li></ul><p>O06 assumed the background source population to lie at a redshift of <em>z<sub>s</sub></em> = 2, and the source luminosity function, \u03a6(<em>z<sub>s</sub></em>, <em>L</em>)\u221d<em>L</em><sup>\u22122.1</sup> appropriate for the radio survey CLASS (Myers et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r75\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r75\">2003</a>; Rusin &amp; Tegmark <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r88\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r88\">2001</a>).<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apj421966fn7\">13</a></sup> We are able to reproduce the expected ISDs from O06, given by Equation (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apj421966fd7\">7</a>), for all the three density distributions mentioned above. The expected ISDs corresponding to these three density distributions are shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj421966f9\">9</a>.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj421966f9\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj421966f9\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966f9_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 9.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 9.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966f9_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 9.</strong>\u00a0Image separation distribution. Theoretically calculated image separation distribution curves for the SIS profile (dotted), NFW profile (dashed), and total profile (solid) following the O06 model. The data points from SLACS (green), <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample (magenta), and MACS (cyan) where the vertical bars indicate Poissonian errors and horizontal bars show the bin width. As discussed in Section <a class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj421966s3-4-2\">3.4.2</a>, we multiply the ISDs of the lens samples by their respective <em>P</em>(&gt; \u2009\u03b8<sub>cut</sub>).</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj421966f9\" href=\"/0004-637X/749/1/38/downloadFigure/figure/apj421966f9\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj421966f9\" href=\"/0004-637X/749/1/38/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj421966f9\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure></div><h4 id=\"apj421966s3-4-2\" name=\"apj421966s3-4-2\">3.4.2.\u00a0Observed Distribution</h4><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The observed ISD is calculated by logarithmically binning the image separations of 125 <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> candidates<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apj421966fn8\">14</a></sup> with \u03b8<sub>cut</sub> &#x2265; 20\u00a0pixels (that is, &gt;3<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />7) and an average ranking of 2 and above. The image separation for each lens candidate is taken as twice the Einstein radius or roughly the arc radius, which is the distance between the candidate lensed image and the center of respective lens galaxy. Let \u03b8 \u2212 <em>d</em>\u03b8 = \u03b8<sub>l</sub> and \u03b8 + <em>d</em>\u03b8 = \u03b8<sub>h</sub>; then the observed ISD is given by\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj421966fd11\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966fd11.gif\" alt=\"Equation (11)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray} \\bigg |\\frac{{\\it dP}_{\\rm lens}}{d\\theta }\\bigg |_{\\rm obs}&=&\\frac{P(>\\theta _{\\rm h}) - P(>\\theta _{\\rm l})}{2d\\theta } \\nonumber \\\\ &=&\\frac{ N(>\\theta _{\\rm h}) - N(>\\theta _{\\rm l})}{N(>\\theta _{\\rm cut}) 2d\\theta } \\, , \\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t11\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where the total number of observed lenses is <em>N</em>(&gt; \u03b8<sub>cut</sub>). While comparing their theoretical predictions (<em>dP</em>/<em>d</em>\u03b8) to the observed ISDs from the CLASS sample, O06 assumed an arbitrary normalization for their data points. Instead we note that,\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj421966fd12\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966fd12.gif\" alt=\"Equation (12)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray} P_{\\rm lens}(>\\theta) &=&\\frac{N_{\\rm lens}(>\\theta)}{N_{\\rm lens}(>\\theta _{\\rm cut})} \\nonumber \\\\ &=&\\frac{N_{\\rm lens}(>\\theta)}{N_{\\rm src}}\\frac{N_{\\rm src}}{N_{\\rm lens}(>\\theta _{\\rm cut})}\\,, \\nonumber \\\\ &=& \\frac{P(>\\theta)}{P(>\\theta _{\\rm cut})}\\,, \\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t12\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj421966fd13\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966fd13.gif\" alt=\"Equation (13)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray} \\Rightarrow \\bigg |\\frac{dP}{d\\theta }\\bigg | &=& \\bigg |\\frac{dP_{\\rm lens}}{d\\theta }\\bigg |\\,P(>\\theta _{\\rm cut})\\,. \\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t13\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>To facilitate a direct comparison of the observed ISD to the theoretical expectation from O06 (see Equation (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apj421966fd7\">7</a>)), we multiply Equation (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apj421966fd11\">11</a>) by <em>P</em>(&gt; \u03b8<sub>cut</sub>). The quantity <em>P</em>(&gt; \u03b8<sub>cut</sub>) is obtained by integrating Equation (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apj421966fd7\">7</a>) from \u03b8<sub>cut</sub> to <b>&#x221e;</b>. The <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> data points are shown in magenta in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj421966f9\">9</a>. The vertical error bars are calculated assuming Poisson number statistics and the horizontal bars show the bin width.</p><p>The <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> data points demonstrate that the average density profile of the halos, giving rise to the intermediate \u03b8 values (~3''\u201312''), is best represented by a combined profile for the main galaxy and the dark matter halo as opposed to a pure SIS or pure NFW profile. It is clear from Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj421966f9\">9</a> that the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample follows a steeper ISD at the intermediate scales compared to halos with NFW profile and shallower than halos with only SIS profile.</p><p>It is interesting to compare the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample with the SLACS and MACS samples which span the lower end and higher end of the ISD, respectively. These samples also have different selection functions compared to the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample. We apply the same procedure to calculate the observed ISD for SLACS and MACS data points shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj421966f9\">9</a>. Intriguingly, the SLACS data points lie in the regime where the SIS density profile just ceases to be dominant. Although the SLACS sample appears to be incomplete by a factor of two to three in the lowest \u03b8 bin, the ISD of SLACS could be seen as an extrapolation of the ISD from the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample. As expected, the MACS sample is nearly consistent with either the NFW or total profile. Assuming that incompleteness is the only major factor in the ISD of SLACS, the expected ISD corresponding to the total profile best matches the SLACS, <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span>, and MACS samples combined.</p><p>We note that we have not accounted for any effects due to purity or incompleteness of the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample in this paper. We suspect that the completeness of the sample as a function of the image separation is not severely affected due to the selection function. We are currently investigating this issue and the results will be presented in a forthcoming paper.</p></div><h4 id=\"apj421966s3-4-3\" name=\"apj421966s3-4-3\">3.4.3.\u00a0Tests with Varying Models</h4><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Here, we test the effects of varying the different components of the O06 model and compare them against the observed ISD. Since different models have different values of <em>P</em>(&gt; \u03b8<sub>cut</sub>), we predict <em>dP</em><sub>lens</sub>/<em>d</em>\u03b8 from each model and compare it with the observed ISD in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj421966f10\">10</a>. We test only for image separations spanning the observed \u03b8 values. In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj421966f9\">9</a> and both panels of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj421966f10\">10</a>, the solid line represents the same ISD corresponding to the total two-component profile, which accounts for the contraction of the dark matter. First, we test the influence of excluding the AC while computing the total profile. This has the effect of making the expected ISD shallower as shown by the dash-dotted curve in the left panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj421966f10\">10</a>. Prima facie, the AC model fits the data better than the model without AC. However, as we show below, there are other\u00a0degeneracies in the model which prevent us from ruling out the \"no AC\" model at high significance.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj421966f10\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj421966f10\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966f10_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 10.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 10.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966f10_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 10.</strong>\u00a0Image separation distribution. Theoretical curves for the total profile, shown with the solid black line, are the same as in Figure <a href=\"#apj421966f9\">9</a>. Left: adopting the <em>c</em>\u2013<em>M</em> relation of M07 (dashed) steepens the total profile. The dotted curve, with <em>M</em>\u2013<em>L</em> relation of Y08 and <em>c</em>\u2013<em>M</em> relation of M07, steepens further but negligibly. The total profile without the AC (dash-dotted) is also shown. Right: the effect of varying \u03b1<sub>LF</sub> on the ISD is shown for the total profile. The total profile without any bias (dashed) is independent of \u03b1<sub>LF</sub>. Changes in various model parameters have\u00a0degenerate effects on the expected ISD. The current uncertainties on the data do not have further constraining power on the tested model parameters. All of the theoretical curves are multiplied by the <em>P</em>(&gt;\u2009\u03b8<sub>3<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />7</sub>) since the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample consists of lenses with \u03b8 &gt; 3<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />7.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj421966f10\" href=\"/0004-637X/749/1/38/downloadFigure/figure/apj421966f10\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj421966f10\" href=\"/0004-637X/749/1/38/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj421966f10\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>Next, we test the effect of using different <em>c</em>\u2013<em>M</em> relations on the ISD. For example, we use the <em>c</em>\u2013<em>M</em> relation by Macci\u00f2 et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r61\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r61\">2007</a>, henceforth M07) instead of that given by Bullock et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r15\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r15\">2001</a>). The <em>c</em>\u2013<em>M</em> relation of M07 is roughly 15%\u201320% lower than that of Bullock et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r15\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r15\">2001</a>). The combined profile using the <em>c</em>\u2013<em>M</em> relation of M07 is shown by the dashed curve in the left panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj421966f10\">10</a>. Within the current statistical limits on the data, both of the <em>c</em>\u2013<em>M</em> relations appear plausible, although the data appears to slightly favor the <em>c</em>\u2013<em>M</em> relation of M07. Since the <em>c</em>\u2013<em>M</em> relations differ significantly at small and large image separations, we will need additional samples of galaxy or cluster-scale lenses to test between the different <em>c</em>\u2013<em>M</em> relations.</p><p>We also test the effect of using a more recent determination of the <em>M</em>\u2013<em>L</em> relation obtained by Yang et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r110\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r110\">2008</a>, henceforth Y08) from a sample of SDSS groups along with the <em>c</em>\u2013<em>M</em> relation of M07 for the combined total profile. The <em>M</em>\u2013<em>L</em> relation of Y08 differs by ~0.2 dex from that of Vale &amp; Ostriker (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r103\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r103\">2004</a>) at the intermediate-mass regime, which is the regime of interest. This appears to cause a very negligible change in the predicted ISD.</p><p>We try to quantify the effect of varying the slope of the source luminosity function at the faint end. We show the effect on the combined profile of O06 and vary the power-law index, \u03b1<sub>LF</sub>, of the source luminosity function, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966ieqn6.gif\" alt=\"$\\Phi (z_s,L)\\propto L^{\\alpha _{\\rm LF}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\Phi (z_s,L)\\propto L^{\\alpha _{\\rm LF}}</script></span></span>. This influences the lens cross section via the magnification bias. The solid curve in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj421966f10\">10</a> shows the expected ISD using the fiducial value of \u03b1<sub>LF</sub> = \u22122.1, while the dotted and short-dashed curves show the ISD in the right panel, corresponding to \u03b1<sub>LF</sub> equal to \u22121.7 and \u22121.2, respectively. It is evident from the figure that the observed ISD can be used to constrain the slope of the luminosity function, if the statistical error bars could be reduced.</p><p>We note that the magnification bias factor in the biased lens cross section is calculated assuming that the background sources are point sources such as quasars. However, the background sources corresponding to the lensed arcs are mostly galaxies with extended surface brightness and their magnification bias could be negligible (e.g., Narayan &amp; Wallington <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r76\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r76\">1993</a>). Therefore, we calculate the ISD assuming no bias, that is, by substituting <em>B</em>(<em>z</em><sub>s</sub>) = 1 in Equation (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apj421966fd5\">5</a>). The long-dashed curve in the right panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj421966f10\">10</a> shows the ISD without the bias.</p><p>The data are consistent with all of the above tested models within the uncertainties. The various scaling relations from our model that are tested here have degenerate effects on the expected ISD. For example, varying the <em>c</em>\u2013<em>M</em> relation has the same effect as changing the slope of the luminosity function or excluding AC. However, constraints from independent observations such as dynamics and strong lensing could be used to determine the <em>c</em>\u2013<em>M</em> relation. This will allow us to better constrain the slope of the luminosity function or make more robust statements about AC.</p><p>For all of the theoretical calculations, we have assumed <em>z</em> = 2 for the source redshift. We checked the effect of adopting different source redshifts, <em>z<sub>s</sub></em> = 1.5 and <em>z<sub>s</sub></em> = 3.0, on the predicted ISD. We found that using a higher (lower) source redshift causes the predicted <em>dP</em>/<em>d</em>\u03b8 to be larger (smaller) by roughly a constant factor at all values of \u03b8. However, the predicted <em>dP</em><sub>lens</sub>/<em>d</em>\u03b8 is not affected because the corresponding increase (decrease) in <em>P</em>(&gt; \u03b8<sub>cut</sub>) almost perfectly cancels out the increase (decrease) in <em>dP</em>/<em>d</em>\u03b8. This implies that the expected ISD would not be drastically different had we accounted for the distribution of source redshifts instead of assuming a single value for the source redshift.</p></div></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj421966s4\" name=\"apj421966s4\">4.\u00a0SUMMARY</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>We have presented the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample from the completed <span class=\"small-caps\">CFHTLS-WIDE</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">CFHTLS-DEEP</span> covering a combined unmasked area of ~150\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> in the sky. The lens sample is compiled through a semi-automatic technique consisting of using the <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> algorithm, followed by visual inspection and ranking of the candidates. We briefly described how <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> works (Alard <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r1\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r1\">2006</a>) and the modifications implemented in the newer version of the algorithm. Although <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> V2.0 is faster, there is still scope for improving the algorithm in terms of increasing the purity without compromising the completeness of the arc detections.</p><p>We have compiled a total of 127 candidates in the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample, out of which 38 are found serendipitously. From the complete sample, 54 are promising lens systems (ranking of 3 and above). A total of 31 systems are almost certain or confirmed systems, out of which 27 systems have been followed up via techniques such as spectroscopy, high-resolution imaging, and/or lens mass modeling. We found two radial arc candidates in the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample and both of them are located in the system SA100. The second radial arc is clearly identified from the high-resolution <em>HST</em> imaging only. Our sample may have more radial arcs, which could be discovered with high-resolution imaging. With statistics of radial and tangential arcs from a homogeneous and a larger sample of lenses, interesting constraints could be placed on the slope of inner density profiles of the dark matter distribution.</p><p>We have discovered a total of 12 giant arcs (<em>l</em>/<em>w</em> &#x2265; 8) in our sample. Statistics with giant arcs is considered to be a good probe of cluster properties or cosmological parameters but not an easy one. We have presented the redshift distributions of the lens galaxies with giant arcs and all arcs in the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample using the photometric redshifts and found them to have mean values at <em>z</em>\u2009 ~ \u20090.6. This is somewhat higher than the expected peak at redshift of 0.3\u20130.4 (Bartelmann et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r7\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r7\">1998</a>) but is consistent within the uncertainties. Note that the predictions need to be revised with improved simulations and more realistic assumptions. We also calculated the angular distribution of giant arcs which are sensitive to the ellipticity of the halo. We found an anisotropy in the orientation of arcs in our sample consistent with that seen in simulated lens clusters (e.g., see D04). In addition, the angular distribution of all arcs from the <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample exhibits similar anisotropy. This anisotropy appears to hold at all arc radii within the current uncertainties albeit needs to be verified with a sample of confirmed lenses. Thus, we have extended this result to group-scale halos, observationally. It would be interesting to check if lensed arcs in simulated group-scale halos also show a similar anisotropy in their azimuthal distribution and what constraints could be placed on the baryonic physics important in the inner few kiloparsecs, which is probed by these lensed arcs.</p><p>We followed the formalism of O06 to calculate the expected ISD in order to compare it with the observed ISD from <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample. We first reproduced the results of O06 and then introduced variations in different scaling relations used in their model. The <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample allowed us, for the first time, to probe the intermediate-mass regime corresponding to group-scale halos via the ISD. We showed that the density profile of the halos are reproduced well by a combined profile (NFW and Hernquist) at the group scales, which is consistent with the predictions. Given the uncertainties in the data and the degeneracies in the model, both of the models that account for or exclude the role of AC are consistent with the observed ISD. With the availability of larger statistics of confirmed lenses and understanding of the sample selection function, the distinction between models with and without AC would be possible.</p><p>Next, we varied the <em>c</em>\u2013<em>M</em> relation, the halo-mass\u2013luminosity relation, the slope of a power-law source luminosity function, and the source redshift. We found that given the current uncertainties in the observed ISD, the <em>c</em>\u2013<em>M</em> relations of both Bullock et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r15\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r15\">2001</a>) and the more recent, Macci\u00f2 et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj421966r61\" id=\"fnref-apj421966r61\">2007</a>), are plausible. The expected ISD does not vary significantly and fits the data well, if the halo-mass\u2013luminosity relations have an uncertainty of ~0.2 dex. Following O06, we adopted a power-law index of \u03b1<sub>LF</sub> = \u22122.1 for the background source luminosity function to account for the magnification bias. We further tested the effect of varying the \u03b1<sub>LF</sub> on the expected ISD and found it to be consistent with the data. However, within the uncertainties, the data are also consistent, if no magnification bias is assumed. We did not test the effects of any evolution of the luminosity function or any other functional form such as a broken power law.</p><p>We found that varying the model parameters has degenerate effects on the ISD, for instance, changing the <em>c</em>\u2013<em>M</em> relation and changing the slope of the luminosity function, \u03b1<sub>LF</sub>. Therefore, using priors from independent methods on one of these relations could help in constraining the others via the observed ISD. Since the background sources are assumed to be at a redshift of 2, we tested the effect of varying the source redshift. The expected ISD (<em>dP</em><sub>lens</sub>/<em>d</em>\u03b8) is not affected by choosing different redshifts (<em>z<sub>s</sub></em> = 1, 2, 3) between the range we tested.</p><p>As described above, we have used arcs statistics to probe the average density profiles of group-scale lenses and we have shown the possibility to use arcs statistics in constraining some scaling relations. However, the models assumed in our work are simplistic and will need refinement as the lens samples become larger with upcoming surveys. On the observational side, understanding the selection effects will also become crucial, if the model parameters need to be constrained with high accuracy. We hope to address some of these important issues in future studies.</p></div><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>The authors acknowledge support from CNRS and ANR grant ANR-06-BLAN-0067. R.G. acknowledges support from the Centre National des Etudes Spatiales. V.M. gratefully acknowledges support from FONDECYT through grant 1090673. A.M. thanks Neal Dalal, Sherry Suyu, and Tomas Verdugo for useful suggestions. A.M. also appreciates comments from the referee which improved the structure and content of the paper. M.L. acknowledges the Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique (CNRS) for its support. The Dark Cosmology Centre is funded by the Danish National Research Foundation. The authors recognize and acknowledge the very significant cultural role and reverence that the summit of Mauna Kea has always had within the indigenous Hawaiian community. We are most fortunate to have the opportunity to conduct observations from this mountain. Tests with varying models of ISD used in this work have been performed on the Joint Fermilab\u2013KICP Supercomputing Cluster, supported by grants from Fermilab, the Kavli Institute for Cosmological Physics, and the University of Chicago.</p><p><em>Facilities:</em> CFHT - Canada-France-Hawaii Telescope, VLT:Antu - Very Large Telescope (Antu)</p></div><h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj421966app1\" name=\"apj421966app1\">APPENDIX A: NUMERICAL DETERMINATION OF LENSING QUANTITIES</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>We describe how we numerically determined the relation between the halo mass and the image separation, the size of radial caustic, and the position-dependent magnification for general spherically symmetric mass distributions. These are used in the calculation of the expected ISD in the two models we tested, namely, the NFW and the total (NFW and Hernquist) profiles.</p><p>Let the position of the lens in the plane of the sky be the origin of the coordinate system. The lensing equation relates the true angular position, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966ieqn7.gif\" alt=\"${\\boldsymbol{\\beta }}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\boldsymbol{\\beta }}</script></span></span>, of the background source to the observed angular position of its image, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966ieqn8.gif\" alt=\"${\\boldsymbol{\\theta }}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\boldsymbol{\\theta }}</script></span></span>, in the plane of the sky, such that\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj421966fd14\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966fd14.gif\" alt=\"Equation (A1)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{equation} {\\boldsymbol{\\beta }} = {\\boldsymbol{\\theta }} - {\\boldsymbol{\\alpha }}({\\boldsymbol{\\theta }}) \\,, \\end{equation}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\tA1\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966ieqn9.gif\" alt=\"${\\boldsymbol{\\alpha }}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\boldsymbol{\\alpha }}</script></span></span> is the scaled deflection angle. In the case of a spherically symmetric density distribution for the lens, the deflection angle <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966ieqn10.gif\" alt=\"${\\boldsymbol{\\alpha }}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\boldsymbol{\\alpha }}</script></span></span> lies along the same direction as \u03b8, and the lens equation can be written as\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj421966fd15\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966fd15.gif\" alt=\"Equation (A2)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{equation} {{\\beta }}={{\\theta }}-\\frac{\\alpha (\\theta)}{\\theta }{{\\theta }} \\,, \\end{equation}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\tA2\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where the quantities not in bold are the magnitudes of the corresponding vectors in bold. The relation between the deflection angle \u03b1 and the magnitude of the image position \u03b8 is given by\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj421966fd16\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966fd16.gif\" alt=\"Equation (A3)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{equation} \\alpha (\\theta)=\\frac{4GM(<D_l\\theta)}{c^2D_l\\theta } \\,, \\end{equation}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\tA3\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where <em>D<sub>l</sub></em> is the angular diameter distance to the lens and <em>M</em>(&lt; <em>D<sub>l</sub></em>\u03b8) denotes the projected lens mass within a physical radius of size \u03be = <em>D<sub>l</sub></em>\u03b8, which can be obtained using the following equation:\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj421966fd17\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966fd17.gif\" alt=\"Equation (A4)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex;
