mode=display\">\\begin{equation} M(<\\xi) = 2\\pi \\int _{0}^{\\xi } R^{\\prime } dR^{\\prime } \\int _{0}^{R_{\\rm max}} 2 \\, \\rho \\left(\\sqrt{z^2+R^{\\prime 2}}\\right) dz \\,, \\end{equation}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\tA4\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966ieqn11.gif\" alt=\"$R_{\\rm max}=\\sqrt{R_{\\rm vir}^2-\\xi ^2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">R_{\\rm max}=\\sqrt{R_{\\rm vir}^2-\\xi ^2}</script></span></span> and <em>R</em><sub>vir</sub> is the virial radius.</p><p>In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj421966f11\">11</a>, we show the generic shape of how \u03b2 and \u03b8 are related to each other for a spherically symmetric mass distribution which has a finite density at the center (non-singular). For large values of \u03b2, \u03b8 \u2248 \u03b2, corresponding to the weak-lensing regime. As the source approaches the lens in projection, i.e., as \u03b2 \u2192 0, the source position \u03b2 corresponds to multiple values of \u03b8, referred to as the strong-lensing regime. The first instance of this is when the source is at the radial caustic (labeled as RC in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj421966f11\">11</a>) and here, the numerical derivative of \u03b2 with respect to \u03b8 is zero. When \u03b2 \u2248 0, \u03b8 corresponds to the Einstein radius (\u03b8<sub><em>E</em></sub>) which is the location of the tangential critical curve (see TCC in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj421966f11\">11</a>). The image separation is approximately equal to 2\u03b8<sub><em>E</em></sub>.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj421966f11\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj421966f11\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966f11_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 11.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 11.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966f11_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 11.</strong>\u00a0Source position as a function of image position for spherically symmetric lens density distribution. The center of the lens potential is at the origin. RC is the location of the radial caustic and TCC is the location of the tangential critical curve which corresponds to the Einstein radius.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj421966f11\" href=\"/0004-637X/749/1/38/downloadFigure/figure/apj421966f11\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj421966f11\" href=\"/0004-637X/749/1/38/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj421966f11\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>The magnification of the lensed image at \u03b8 is given by the determinant of\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj421966fd18\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966fd18.gif\" alt=\"Equation (A5)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{equation} \\mu (\\theta) = \\left| \\frac{\\partial {\\boldsymbol{\\beta }}}{\\partial {\\boldsymbol{\\theta }}} \\right|^{-1} \\,. \\end{equation}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\tA5\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>In component notation, the required derivative is given by\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj421966fd19\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966fd19.gif\" alt=\"Equation (A6)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray} \\frac{\\partial \\beta _i}{\\partial \\theta _j} &=& \\delta _{ij}\\left(1-\\frac{\\alpha }{\\theta }\\right) - \\frac{\\partial }{\\partial \\theta }\\left(\\frac{\\alpha }{\\theta } - 1 \\right)\\frac{\\partial \\theta }{\\partial \\theta _j}\\theta _i \\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\tA6\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj421966fd20\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966fd20.gif\" alt=\"Equation (A7)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray} &=& \\delta _{ij}\\frac{\\beta }{\\theta }+ \\frac{\\partial }{\\partial \\theta }\\left(\\frac{\\beta }{\\theta } \\right)\\frac{\\theta _i\\theta _j}{\\theta } \\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\tA7\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj421966fd21\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966fd21.gif\" alt=\"Equation (A8)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray} &=& \\delta _{ij}\\frac{\\beta }{\\theta }+ \\left(\\frac{\\partial \\beta }{\\partial \\theta } - \\frac{\\beta }{\\theta } \\right)\\frac{\\theta _i\\theta _j}{\\theta ^2} \\,. \\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\tA8\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>The inverse of the determinant of the above equation simplifies to\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj421966fd22\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966fd22.gif\" alt=\"Equation (A9)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{equation} \\mu (\\theta) = \\frac{\\theta }{\\beta } \\frac{\\partial \\theta }{\\partial \\beta } \\,. \\end{equation}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\tA9\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>To summarize, given a spherically symmetric density distribution \u03c1(<em>r</em>), we first obtain the value of \u03b2 for different values of \u03b8 using Equations (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apj421966fd15\">A2</a>)\u2013(<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apj421966fd17\">A4</a>). We use cubic splines to approximate the function \u03b2(\u03b8). The value of \u03b2 which corresponds to the local extrema of this function gives the angular size of the radial caustic. The image separation is given by two times the value of \u03b8 when \u03b2 = 0. The mass within this angular image separation can be calculated using Equation (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apj421966fd17\">A4</a>). Finally, the magnification as a function of \u03b8 can be obtained using Equation (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apj421966fd22\">A9</a>). The required derivative is calculated by using the cubic spline fit. The magnification bias can thus be calculated using Equation (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apj421966fd6\">6</a>).</p></div><h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj421966app2\" name=\"apj421966app2\">APPENDIX B: MEASUREMENT OF THE PEAK OF THE REDSHIFT DISTRIBUTION</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>Consider a lensing galaxy with true redshift <em>z<sub>t</sub></em> for which the photometric redshift estimate is <em>z<sub>i</sub></em> \u00b1 \u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub>. Let us assume that the true redshifts of the lens population follow a Gaussian distribution, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966ieqn12.gif\" alt=\"$G(\\bar{z}_t,\\sigma _t^2)$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">G(\\bar{z}_t,\\sigma _t^2)</script></span></span>, with the mean and variance given by <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966ieqn13.gif\" alt=\"$\\bar{z}_t$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\bar{z}_t</script></span></span> and \u03c3<sup>2</sup><sub><em>t</em></sub>, respectively. The probability that the estimated redshift of the lens galaxy is equal to <em>z<sub>i</sub></em>, is then given by\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj421966fd23\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966fd23.gif\" alt=\"Equation (B1)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray} P(z_i|G)&=&\\int P(z_i|z_t) P(z_t|G) dz_t \\,, \\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\tB1\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj421966fd24\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966fd24.gif\" alt=\"Equation (B2)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray} &=& \\frac{1}{2\\pi } \\int \\frac{1}{\\sigma _i \\sigma _t} {\\rm exp} \\left[ - \\left(\\frac{(z_i-z_t)^2}{2\\sigma _i^2} + \\frac{(z_t-\\bar{z}_t)^2}{2\\sigma _t^2} \\right)\\right] dz_t.\\nonumber\\\\ \\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\tB2\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>Rewriting the factor inside the exponential as a quadratic in <em>z<sub>t</sub></em> and completing the square yields\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj421966fd25\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966fd25.gif\" alt=\"Equation (B3)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray} P(z_i|G)&=&\\frac{1}{2 \\pi \\sigma _i \\sigma _t} {\\rm exp} \\left[ \\frac{-(z_i-\\bar{z}_t)^2}{ 2(\\sigma _i^2+\\sigma _t^2) } \\right]\\nonumber\\\\ &&\\times\\int {\\rm exp} \\left[ \\frac{- [ z_t - \\tilde{z} ]^2}{2} \\left(\\frac{1}{\\sigma _i^2} + \\frac{1}{\\sigma _t^2}\\right) \\right] dz_t, \\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\tB3\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966ieqn14.gif\" alt=\"$\\tilde{z}=(\\sigma _i^2+\\sigma _t^2)^{-1} (z_i\\sigma _i^{-2} + {\\bar{z}}_t\\sigma _t^{-2})$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\tilde{z}=(\\sigma _i^2+\\sigma _t^2)^{-1} (z_i\\sigma _i^{-2} + {\\bar{z}}_t\\sigma _t^{-2})</script></span></span>. Carrying out the integral gives\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj421966fd26\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966fd26.gif\" alt=\"Equation (B4)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray} P(z_i|G)&=&\\frac{1}{\\sqrt{2 \\pi \\big(\\sigma _i^2 + \\sigma _t^2\\big)}} {\\rm exp} \\left[ \\frac{-(z_i-\\bar{z}_t)^2}{ 2(\\sigma _i^2+\\sigma _t^2) } \\right] \\,. \\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\tB4\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>Since the determinations of the photometric redshifts of lens galaxies are independent of each other, the combined likelihood for the data, given our model, can be written as <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966ieqn15.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathscr{L}= \\prod _{i=1}^{N} P(z_i|G)$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathscr{L}= \\prod _{i=1}^{N} P(z_i|G)</script></span></span>. The posterior distribution for our model parameters given the data is then given by Bayes' theorem\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj421966fd27\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966fd27.gif\" alt=\"Equation (B5)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray} &&P\\big(\\bar{z}_t,\\sigma _t^2 | z_i,\\sigma _i\\big) \\propto \\mathscr{L}\\, P\\big(\\bar{z}_t,\\sigma _t^2\\big). \\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\tB5\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>We assume uninformative priors on the parameters <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/749/1/38/Full/apj421966ieqn16.gif\" alt=\"$\\bar{z}_t$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\bar{z}_t</script></span></span> and \u03c3<sup>2</sup><sub><em>t</em></sub> and sample from the above posterior distribution using a Monte Carlo Markov Chain. We quote the mean of the redshift distribution and the 68% confidence interval on it using the samples from the chain.</p></div></div><!-- End article full text -->\n<!-- Start Footnotes -->\n\t<h2 id=\"footnotes\">Footnotes</h2>\n\t\t<div data-mobile-collapse=\"\">\n\t\t\t<ul class=\"clear-list wd-content-footnotes\">\n\t\t\t\t<li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"apj421966fn1\" id=\"apj421966fn1\">*\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><p class=\"mb-0\"><p>Based on observations obtained with MegaPrime/MegaCam, a joint project of CFHT and CEA/DAPNIA, at the Canada\u2013France\u2013Hawaii Telescope (CFHT) which is operated by the National Research Council (NRC) of Canada, the Institut National des Science de l'Univers of the Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique (CNRS) of France, and the University of Hawaii. This work is based in part on data products produced at TERAPIX and the Canadian Astronomy Data Centre as part of the Canada\u2013France\u2013Hawaii Telescope Legacy Survey, a collaborative project of NRC and CNRS.</p></p></div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"apj421966fn2\" id=\"apj421966fn2\">8\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><p class=\"mb-0\"><p>These numbers are estimated from <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"url_link\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"http://terapix.iap.fr/cplt/table_syn_T0006.html\">http://terapix.iap.fr/cplt/table_syn_T0006.html</a>.</p></p></div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"apj421966fn3\" id=\"apj421966fn3\">9\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><p class=\"mb-0\"><p><a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"url_link\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"http://terapix.iap.fr/cplt/T0006-doc.pdf\">http://terapix.iap.fr/cplt/T0006-doc.pdf</a></p></p></div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"apj421966fn4\" id=\"apj421966fn4\">10\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><p class=\"mb-0\"><p>High-resolution images of these systems are made available at <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"url_link\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"http://kicp.uchicago.edu/~anupreeta/sarcs_sample\">http://kicp.uchicago.edu/~anupreeta/sarcs_sample</a>.</p></p></div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"apj421966fn5\" id=\"apj421966fn5\">11\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><p class=\"mb-0\"><p><a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"url_link\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"http://www.cfa.harvard.edu/castles/\">http://www.cfa.harvard.edu/castles/</a></p></p></div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"apj421966fn6\" id=\"apj421966fn6\">12\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><p class=\"mb-0\"><p>For lens models with spherical symmetry that are considered here, the radial caustic is the outermost caustic and a source lying within the outermost caustic gets strongly lensed, i.e., multiply imaged.</p></p></div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"apj421966fn7\" id=\"apj421966fn7\">13\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><p class=\"mb-0\"><p>The luminosity density for such a steep faint-end slope (\u03b1<sub>LF</sub> &lt; \u22122) diverges as <em>L</em> \u2192 0 and necessarily requires a cutoff below some value of <em>L</em><sub>min</sub>.</p></p></div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"apj421966fn8\" id=\"apj421966fn8\">14\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><p class=\"mb-0\"><p>Two of the candidates are excluded since their lensing configurations or the centers of their lens potential were ambiguous. These candidates have <em>R</em><sub>A</sub> = 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />0 in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj421966t2\">2</a>.</p></p></div></li></ul>\n\t\t</div>\n\t<!-- End Footnotes -->\t\n<!-- Start References List -->\n\n<div By continuing to use this site you agree to our use of cookies.</small></li>\n                    </ul>\n                </div>\n            </nav>\n            </div>\n        </div> <!-- end wrapper -->\n    </div> <!-- end iopp-footer -->\n</footer>\n<!-- Footer tile ends -->\n<script>\n  var imgBase = \"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img\";\n  /*  Cutting the mustard - http://responsivenews.co.uk/post/18948466399/cutting-the-mustard */\n\n  /* This is the original if statement, from the link above. I have amended it to turn of JS on all IE browsers less than 10.\n\tThis is due to a function in the iop.jquery.toolbar.js line 35/36. Uses .remove which is not native js supported in IE9 or lower */\n  /* if('querySelector' in document \n\t&& 'localStorage' in window\n\t&& 'addEventListener' in window) { */\n\n  /* This is the updated selector, taken from: https://justmarkup.com/log/2015/02/26/cut-the-mustard-revisited/ */\n\tif('visibilityState' in document) {\n\n\t/*! loadJS: load a JS file asynchronously. [c]2014 @scottjehl, Filament Group, Inc. (Based on http://goo.gl/REQGQ by Paul Irish).. Licensed MIT */\n\tfunction loadJS( src, cb ){\n\t  \"use strict\";\n\t  var ref = window.document.getElementsByTagName( \"script\" )[ 0 ];\n\t  var script = window.document.createElement( \"script\" );\n\t  script.src = src;\n\t  script.async = true;\n\t  ref.parentNode.insertBefore( script, ref );\n\t  if (cb && typeof(cb) === \"function\") {\n\t\tscript.onload = cb;\n\t  }\n\t  return script;\n\t}\n\n\tloadJS( \"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/js/scripts.min.js\" );\n\n  }\n</script>\n\n<script type=\"text/javascript\">window.NREUM||(NREUM={});NREUM.info={\"errorBeacon\":\"bam-cell.nr-data.net\",\"licenseKey\":\"b2bfaae1b6\",\"agent\":\"\",\"beacon\":\"bam-cell.nr-data.net\",\"applicationTime\":543,\"applicationID\":\"723879338\",\"transactionName\":\"NAAHMUBVCENSABFZXg1KLzZiGzF1cU4sfndMDxYVQRsFX14OCl4eDwQcCkdASFpAEw==\",\"queueTime\":0}</script></body>\n</html>", "Tables status": "Complete", "Inspection status": "Complete", "Paper Overview": {"abstract": "We present the Strong Lensing Legacy Survey-ARCS (SARCS) sample compiled from the final T0006 data release of the Canada-France-Hawaii Telescope Legacy Survey (CFHTLS) covering a total non-overlapping area of 159 deg<SUP>2</SUP>. We adopt a semi-automatic method to find gravitational arcs in the survey that makes use of an arc-finding algorithm. The candidate list is pruned by visual inspection and ranking to form the final SARCS sample. This list also includes some serendipitously discovered lens candidates which the automated algorithm did not detect. The SARCS sample consists of 127 lens candidates which span arc radii ~2''-18'' within the unmasked area of ~150 deg<SUP>2</SUP>. Within the sample, 54 systems are promising lenses among which, we find 12 giant arcs (length-to-width ratio &gt;=8). We also find two radial arc candidates in SL2SJ141447+544704. From our sample, we detect a systematic alignment of the giant arcs with the major axis of the baryonic component of the putative lens in concordance with previous studies. This alignment is also observed for all arcs in the sample and does not vary significantly with increasing arc radius. The mean values of the photometric redshift distributions of lenses corresponding to the giant arcs and all arcs sample are at z ~ 0.6. Owing to the large area and depth of the CFHTLS, we find the largest sample of lenses probing mass scales that are intermediate to cluster and galaxy lenses for the first time. We compare the observed image separation distribution (ISD) of our arcs with theoretical models. A two-component density profile for the lenses which accounts for both the central galaxy and the dark matter component is required by the data to explain the observed ISD. Unfortunately, current levels of uncertainties and degeneracies accommodate models both with and without adiabatic contraction. We also show the effects of changing parameters of the model that predict the ISD and that a larger lens sample might constrain relations such as the concentration-mass relation, mass-luminosity relation, and the faint-end slope of the luminosity function. <P />Based on observations obtained with MegaPrime/MegaCam, a joint project of CFHT and CEA/DAPNIA, at the Canada-France-Hawaii Telescope (CFHT) which is operated by the National Research Council (NRC) of Canada, the Institut National des Science de l'Univers of the Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique (CNRS) of France, and the University of Hawaii. This work is based in part on data products produced at TERAPIX and the Canadian Astronomy Data Centre as part of the Canada-France-Hawaii Telescope Legacy Survey, a collaborative project of NRC and CNRS.", "start_page": "38", "authors": ["More, A.", "Cabanac, R.", "More, S.", "Alard, C.", "Limousin, M.", "Kneib, J. -P.", "Gavazzi, R.", "Motta, V."], "custom1": "eprint: arXiv:1109.1821", "issn": "0004-637X", "Title": "The CFHTLS-Strong Lensing Legacy Survey (SL2S): Investigating the Group-scale Lenses with the SARCS Sample", "type_of_reference": "JOUR", "keywords": ["dark matter", "gravitational lensing: strong", "methods: data analysis", "surveys", "Astrophysics - Cosmology and Nongalactic Astrophysics"], "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2012ApJ...749...38M", "journal_name": "The Astrophysical Journal", "volume": "749", "number": "1", "publication_year": "2012/04/1", "doi": "10.1088/0004-637X/749/1/38", "author_address": ["AA(Kavli Institute for Cosmological Physics, University of Chicago, 5640 S. Ellis Ave., Chicago, IL 60637, USA ; Laboratoire d'Astrophysique de Marseille, Universit\u00e9 d'Aix-Marseille &amp; CNRS, UMR7326, 38 rue Fr\u00e9d\u00e9ric Joliot Curie, F-13013 Marseille, France ;), AB(Universit\u00e9 de Toulouse, UPS-OMP, IRAP, Tarbes, France ; CNRS, IRAP, 57, Ave. d'Azereix, F-65000 Tarbes, France), AC(Kavli Institute for Cosmological Physics, University of Chicago, 5640 S. =======
{"Status": "Complete", "ADS link": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2012ApJ...749...38M", "Publisher link via ADS gateway": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/link_gateway/2012ApJ...749...38M/PUB_HTML", "Action": "Scanned and processed all tables", "Paper Overview": {"type_of_reference": "JOUR", "Title": "The CFHTLS-Strong Lensing Legacy Survey (SL2S): Investigating the Group-scale Lenses with the SARCS Sample", "authors": ["More, A.", "Cabanac, R.", "More, S.", "Alard, C.", "Limousin, M.", "Kneib, J. -P.", "Gavazzi, R.", "Motta, V."], "author_address": ["AA(Kavli Institute for Cosmological Physics, University of Chicago, 5640 S. Ellis Ave., Chicago, IL 60637, USA ; Laboratoire d'Astrophysique de Marseille, Universit\u00e9 d'Aix-Marseille &amp; CNRS, UMR7326, 38 rue Fr\u00e9d\u00e9ric Joliot Curie, F-13013 Marseille, France ;), AB(Universit\u00e9 de Toulouse, UPS-OMP, IRAP, Tarbes, France ; CNRS, IRAP, 57, Ave. d'Azereix, F-65000 Tarbes, France), AC(Kavli Institute for Cosmological Physics, University of Chicago, 5640 S. Ellis Ave., Chicago, IL 60637, USA), AD(Institute d'Astrophysique de Paris, 98 Bis Boulevard Arago, F-45014 Paris, France), AE(Laboratoire d'Astrophysique de Marseille, Universit\u00e9 d'Aix-Marseille &amp; CNRS, UMR7326, 38 rue Fr\u00e9d\u00e9ric Joliot Curie, F-13013 Marseille, France ; Dark Cosmology Centre, Niels Bohr Institute, University of Copenhagen, Juliane Maries Vej 30, DK-2100 Copenhagen, Denkmark), AF(Laboratoire d'Astrophysique de Marseille, Universit\u00e9 d'Aix-Marseille &amp; CNRS, UMR7326, 38 rue Fr\u00e9d\u00e9ric Joliot Curie, F-13013 Marseille, France), AG(Institute d'Astrophysique de Paris, 98 Bis Boulevard Arago, F-45014 Paris, France), AH(Departamento de Fisica y Astronomia, Universidad de Valparaiso, Avenida Gran Bretana 1111, Valparaiso, Chile)"], "journal_name": "The Astrophysical Journal", "volume": "749", "publication_year": "2012/04/1", "start_page": "38", "keywords": ["dark matter", "gravitational lensing: strong", "methods: data analysis", "surveys", "Astrophysics - Cosmology and Nongalactic Astrophysics"], "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2012ApJ...749...38M", "abstract": "We present the Strong Lensing Legacy Survey-ARCS (SARCS) sample compiled from the final T0006 data release of the Canada-France-Hawaii Telescope Legacy Survey (CFHTLS) covering a total non-overlapping area of 159 deg<SUP>2</SUP>. We adopt a semi-automatic method to find gravitational arcs in the survey that makes use of an arc-finding algorithm. The candidate list is pruned by visual inspection and ranking to form the final SARCS sample. This list also includes some serendipitously discovered lens candidates which the automated algorithm did not detect. The SARCS sample consists of 127 lens candidates which span arc radii ~2''-18'' within the unmasked area of ~150 deg<SUP>2</SUP>. Within the sample, 54 systems are promising lenses among which, we find 12 giant arcs (length-to-width ratio &gt;=8). We also find two radial arc candidates in SL2SJ141447+544704. From our sample, we detect a systematic alignment of the giant arcs with the major axis of the baryonic component of the putative lens in concordance with previous studies. This alignment is also observed for all arcs in the sample and does not vary significantly with increasing arc radius. The mean values of the photometric redshift distributions of lenses corresponding to the giant arcs and all arcs sample are at z ~ 0.6. Owing to the large area and depth of the CFHTLS, we find the largest sample of lenses probing mass scales that are intermediate to cluster and galaxy lenses for the first time. We compare the observed image separation distribution (ISD) of our arcs with theoretical models. A two-component density profile for the lenses which accounts for both the central galaxy and the dark matter component is required by the data to explain the observed ISD. Unfortunately, current levels of uncertainties and degeneracies accommodate models both with and without adiabatic contraction. We also show the effects of changing parameters of the model that predict the ISD and that a larger lens sample might constrain relations such as the concentration-mass relation, mass-luminosity relation, and the faint-end slope of the luminosity function. <P />Based on observations obtained with MegaPrime/MegaCam, a joint project of CFHT and CEA/DAPNIA, at the Canada-France-Hawaii Telescope (CFHT) which is operated by the National Research Council (NRC) of Canada, the Institut National des Science de l'Univers of the Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique (CNRS) of France, and the University of Hawaii. This work is based in part on data products produced at TERAPIX and the Canadian Astronomy Data Centre as part of the Canada-France-Hawaii Telescope Legacy Survey, a collaborative project of NRC and itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Periodical\">\n        <a name=\"\" id=\"skip-to-content-link-target\" tabindex=\"-1\"></a>\n        <div class=\"wrapper grid-3-col da-showgrid ta-showgrid cf\">\n    <main role=\"main\">\n        <!-- Secondary header starts -->\n<div class=\"secondary-header cf\" id=\"wd-secondary-header\">\n    <!-- Branded journal header starts -->\n<div class=\"big-branded\">\n\n    <div class=\"publication-name\" id=\"wd-pub-name\">\n\t<div class=\"publication-title\" itemprop=\"name\" itemid=\"periodical\">\n\t\t\t\t<!-- Journal image link tile starts -->\n<!-- Logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"/journal/0004-637X\" itemprop=\"url\">\n    <img src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8febf88b-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/apj-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Astrophysical Journal\">\n</a>\n<!-- Logo tile ends -->\n<!-- Journal image link tile ends -->\n</div>\n\t\t</div>\n    <div class=\"partner-logos m-hide\" id=\"wd-partner-logos\">\n            <div class=\"partner-logo-alignment\">\n                <!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8a2230b8-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/aas-2018.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The American Astronomical Society, find out more\">\n</a>\n<span class=\"overlay-set\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel\">\n        <a title=\"Close\"  class=\"close-icon close-overlay\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\" aria-describedby=\"close-icon-description\"><span class=\"icon-close\"></span></a>\n        <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.</p>\n        <div class=\"overlay-img\">\n            <a href=\"\">\n                <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8a2230b8-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/aas-2018.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The American Astronomical Society, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The American Astronomical Society (AAS), established in 1899 and based in Washington, DC, is the major organization of professional astronomers in North America. Its membership of about 7,000 individuals also includes physicists, mathematicians, geologists, engineers, and others whose research and educational interests lie within the broad spectrum of subjects comprising contemporary astronomy. The mission of the AAS is to enhance and share humanity's scientific understanding of the universe.</p> <p><a href=\"https://aas.org/\">https://aas.org/</a></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n</a>\n<span class=\"overlay-set\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel\">\n        <a title=\"Close\"  class=\"close-icon close-overlay\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\" aria-describedby=\"close-icon-description\"><span class=\"icon-close\"></span></a>\n        <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.</p>\n        <div class=\"overlay-img\">\n            <a href=\"\">\n                <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The Institute of Physics (IOP) is a leading scientific society promoting physics and bringing physicists together for the benefit of all. It has a worldwide membership of around 50 000 comprising physicists from all sectors, as well as those with an interest in physics. It works to advance physics research, application and education; and engages with policy makers and the public to develop awareness and understanding of physics. Its publishing company, IOP Publishing, is a world leader in professional scientific communications.</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.iop.org\">https://www.iop.org</a></p></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<p></p>\n                </div>\n        </div>\n    </div>\n<!-- Branded journal header ends -->\n</div> <!-- end secondary-header -->\n<!-- Secondary header ends --><div class=\"da1-da2\" itemscope=\"\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/ScholarlyArticle\" id=\"page-content\">\n            <div class=\"da1 ta1 article-head\">\n                <!-- Start Eyebrow block, containing Surtitle and Labels -->\n<div class=\"eyebrow\">\n\t<!-- Start Collection Labels -->\n    <!-- End Collection Labels --> </div>\n<!-- End Eyebrow block -->\n\n<h1 itemprop=\"headline\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-title\">THE CFHTLS\u2013STRONG LENSING LEGACY SURVEY (SL2S): INVESTIGATING THE GROUP-SCALE LENSES WITH THE SARCS SAMPLE<SUP>*</SUP>       </h1>\n\n<p class=\"mb-0\">\n\t<span data-authors=\"\">\n\t\t<span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">A. More</span><sup>1,2</sup></span>, <span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">R. Cabanac</span><sup>3,4</sup></span>, <span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">S. More</span><sup>1</sup></span>, <span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">C. Alard</span><sup>5</sup></span>, <span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">M. Limousin</span><sup>2,6</sup></span>, <span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">J-P. Kneib</span><sup>2</sup></span>, <span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">R. Gavazzi</span><sup>5</sup></span>, and <span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">V. Motta</span><sup>7</sup></span></span>\n</p>\n\n<p class=\"small\" itemprop=\"isPartOf\" itemscope=\"\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/PublicationIssue\">\n\t<!--Article Breadcrumb Tile Start-->\n<span class=\"wd-jnl-art-pub-date\">Published 2012 March 20</span> &bull; <!-- Start Copyright-->\n    <span itemprop=\"copyrightHolder\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-copyright\">\n       \t  \u00a9 2012. The American Astronomical Society. All rights reserved.</span><br />\n    <!-- end Copyright -->\n<span itemscope itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Periodical\" itemid=\"periodical\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-breadcrumb-title article-toolbar-anchor\">\n\t<span itemprop=\"name\">\n\t\t<a href=\"/journal/0004-637X\" itemprop=\"url\">The Astrophysical Journal</a></span></span>,\n\t<span itemprop=\"isPartOf\" itemscope itemtype=\"http://schema.org/PublicationVolume\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-breadcrumb-vol nowrap\">\n\t<link itemprop=\"isPartOf\" itemid=\"periodical\" itemscope/>\n\t<span itemprop=\"volumeNumber\"><a href=\"/volume/0004-637X/749\" itemprop=\"url\">Volume 749</a></span></span>,\n<span itemprop=\"issueNumber\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-breadcrumb-issue\"><a href=\"/issue/0004-637X/749/1\" itemprop=\"url\"><!--Issue Number Tile Start-->\nNumber 1<!--Issue Number Tile End--></a></span>\n<!--Article Breadcrumb Tile End-->\n<!-- Start Focus issue title -->\n\t<!-- End focus issue title -->\n\t<span style=\"display: block\"><b>Citation</b> A. More <em>et al</em> 2012 <em>ApJ</em> <b>749</b> 38</span>\n    </p>\n\n<div class=\"btn-multi-block mb-1\">\n\t\t<a href=\"/article/10.1088/0004-637X/749/1/38/pdf\" class=\"btn btn-large btn-primary   \" itemprop=\"sameAs\" target = \"_blank\"><span class=\"icon-file-pdf\"></span><span class=\"offscreen-hidden\"> Download </span><span>Article</span> PDF</a>\n</div>\n<!-- Start toolbar -->\n<div                <div class=\"overlay-panel__logo\"></div>\n                    <span id=\"alerts-box-title\" class=\"replica-h2\">Corridor alerts</span>\n                    <p <span class=\"icon-newtab\">\n            </a></p>\n        </div>\n\n    <!-- End Email Alert -->\n<!-- End Email Alert --><!-- Start Citation Alert Link -->\n                        <p>\n<div class=\"jnl-notifications-wrapper\">\n    <a class=\"wd-jnl-email-alert\" href=\"https://myiopscience.iop.org/signin?origin=a0&return=https%3A%2F%2Fiopscience.iop.org%2Fmyiopscience%2Falerts%2Fsubscribe%3FarticleID%3D0004-637X%2F749%2F1%2F38\"><span\n            class=\"icon-alarm icon-alarm--jhp\"></span>Create citation alert</a>\n</div><!-- End Citation Alert Link -->\n                    </div>\n\t\t</div>\n    </div>\n    <!-- Article information ends -->\n<!-- Start Info top-->\n    <!-- end Info top --><div class=\"article-content\">\n\t<span id=\"articleId\" class=\"hide\">0004-637X/749/1/38</span>\n<!-- Start Abstract -->\n    <h2 id=\"artAbst\" class=\"collapse-blocked\">Abstract</h2>\n        <!-- Start article video abstract -->\n\t<!-- End article video abstract -->\n\t<div class=\"article-text wd-jnl-art-abstract cf\" itemprop=\"description\">\n                      <P>We present the Strong Lensing Legacy Survey-ARCS (SARCS) sample compiled from the final T0006 data release of the Canada-France-Hawaii Telescope Legacy Survey (CFHTLS) covering a total non-overlapping area of 159\u00a0deg<SUP>2</SUP>. We adopt a semi-automatic method to find gravitational arcs in the survey that makes use of an arc-finding algorithm. The candidate list is pruned by visual inspection and ranking to form the final <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample. This list also includes some serendipitously discovered lens candidates which the automated algorithm did not detect. The <span class=\"small-caps\">SARCS</span> sample consists of 127 lens candidates which span arc radii ~2''-18'' within the unmasked area of ~150\u00a0deg<SUP>2</SUP>. Within the sample, 54 systems are promising lenses among which, we find 12 giant arcs (length-to-width ratio &#x2265;8). We also find two radial arc candidates in SL2SJ141447+544704. From our sample, we detect a systematic alignment of the giant arcs with the major axis of the baryonic component of the putative lens in concordance with previous studies. This alignment is also observed for all arcs in the sample and does not vary significantly with increasing arc radius. The mean values of the photometric redshift distributions of lenses corresponding to the giant arcs and all arcs sample are at <I>z</I> ~ 0.6. Owing to the large area and depth of the CFHTLS, we find the largest sample of lenses probing mass scales that are intermediate to cluster and galaxy lenses for the first time. We compare the observed image separation distribution (ISD) of our arcs with theoretical models. A two-component density profile for the lenses which accounts for both the central galaxy and the dark matter component is required by the data to explain the observed ISD. Unfortunately, current levels of uncertainties and\u00a0degeneracies accommodate models both with and without adiabatic contraction. We also show the effects of changing parameters of the model that predict the ISD and that a larger lens sample might constrain relations such as the concentration-mass relation, mass-luminosity relation, and the faint-end slope of the luminosity function.</P>       </div>\n    <!-- End abstract -->\n<!-- Start Export citation and abstract tools -->\n\t<p>\n\t\t<small>Export citation and abstract</small>\n\t\t<span class=\"btn-multi-block\">\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/export?articleId=0004-637X/749/1/38&doi=10.1088/0004-637X/749/1/38&exportFormat=iopexport_bib&exportType=abs&navsubmit=Export+abstract\" class=\"btn btn-primary wd-btn-cit-abs-bib\" title=\"Export BibTex\">BibTeX</a>\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/export?articleId=0004-637X/749/1/38&doi=10.1088/0004-637X/749/1/38&exportFormat=iopexport_ris&exportType=abs&navsubmit=Export+abstract\" class=\"btn btn-primary wd-btn-cit-abs-ris\" title=\"Export RIS\">RIS</a>\n\t\t</span>\n\t</p>\n<!-- End Export citation and abstract tools -->\n<!-- Start AAS Related Links -->\n<div class=\"reveal-container reveal-closed reveal-plus-icon bdt-1 mt-2 mb-2 wd-jnl-art-article-aas-related-links\">\n  <div class=\"replica-h3 mt-0\">\n    <a href=\"#\" class=\"reveal-trigger\" data-reveal-label-alt=\"Hide related links\">Related links</a>\n  </div>\n  <div class=\"reveal-content\">\n    <div class=\"article-meta\"> \n      <ul>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2012ApJ...749...38M\" target=\"_blank\">NASA ADS Record <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://nedwww.ipac.caltech.edu/cgi-bin/nph-objsearch?refcode=2012ApJ...749...38M&search_type=Search \" target=\"_blank\">NED Objects <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a
